Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.There is still uncertainty about arrangements for Christmas , but the communities of Southend and Carradale have decided to bring people together in making #community advent calendars#.Starting on December , dferent houses in each parish will decorate a window, and reveal their window on a dferent day of the month. So there will be one window on st December , two windows on December  and so on – and they should stay in place until Twelfth Night.Everyone is invited to walk or drive around the parishes and spot the decorated windows. A guide will also be available in the village shops.In this way, we hope to brighten the preparation for Christmas for everyone.More than , children are admitted to hospital every day in the UK and it has never been a scarier time for them.With unfamiliar wards, health professionals in additional PPE, only being able to have one parent with them, and no visits from their brothers or sisters during the pandemic, it can be very worrying and lonely.That is why play and distraction services in hospitals are now more vital than ever. Having access to toys and entertainment, when recovering or waiting for treatment, or using play as a distraction for procedures can help to alleviate pain, aid recovery and bring joy back into children’s lives.At the children’s charity Starlight, thanks to our supporters, we provide hospitals with boxes filled with toys, games and puzzles to be used on wards.This year, Starlight’s fundraising income has fallen due to many cancelled events, which is why we have started our Time to Play campaign. Our goal is to raise £, before the end of the year to help , children get access to play in hospital and limit the negative effects of illness on their childhood.It’s easy to support and our website has fun ideas of how to take part, including our Stream for Starlight fundraiser for computer gamers.Or,you are able to, please considering making a simple one-off donation. However big or small, it will help Starlight to continue to be there to support children and their families this Christmas.I’m hoping your readers will join together and help support Starlight, to bring back joy into the lives of the , seriously ill children living in the UK this Christmas.Please visit www.starlight.org.uk time to help us. Thank you.Every year thousands of children contact Childline about being bullied online and tell us that they feel it is hard to escape from.Lockdown has intensied these feelings for many and since April we’ve counselled more than , children and young people across the UK about online bullying.Children have told us about people sending threatening or abusive messages and being pressured into engaging in sexual conversations. Others have shared that they’ve been excluded from online games by other children, while some spoke of online identities being stolen to embarrass or cause trouble while using their name.Before lockdown measures were first introduced this year, the average monthly number of counselling sessions with children about online bullying was . Between April and October that value increased by  per cent to a monthly average of .This is worrying, particularly as we continue to adhere to strict social-distancing restrictions across Scotland and children continue to spend more time online. Bullying can have a long-term impact on the mental wellbeing of a child and, as we mark Anti Bullying Week this month and beyond, it’s important to ensure that every child knows who they can turn to for support.If a parent thinks their child is being bullied online, it can be hard to remain calm, but it’s crucial not to overwhelm a child with questions. Taking their device away is likely to make them feel like whatever has happened is their fault instead, it’s helpful to listen to their worries, suggest they take some time away from certain apps, and provide them with reassurance.Adeniyi Alade, service head of Childline at NSPCC Scotland.Boris Johnson’s comment that devolution has been #a disaster north of the border# and #Tony Blair’s worst mistake# should hardly come as a surprise to anyone.The Tories have never been great supporters of devolution, vehemently opposing both the referendums in  on establishing a Scottish Assembly and in  on the Scottish Parliament.Most recently the devolution power grab that is highlighted in the Internal Market Bill simply reinforces this stance.The Scottish Social Attitudes surveyon constitutional preference found that only seven per cent favour abolition of the Scottish Parliament and it found that trust in the Scottish Government sits at four times that of the UK Government. This points to it hardly being a disaster.For those accused of scaremongering that there is a threat to Holyrood, Mr Johnson’s comments are clear vindication. The irony of all this being that devolution has given new le to the Scottish Conservatives after its wipe out in  and it is now the opposition in the Scottish Parliament.Be under no doubt that the Scottish Parliament, which was hard fought for, is under threat and we must do all in our power to defend it.Alex Orr, Edinburgh.While this year Christmas is going to be dferent from usual for many of us, it is still a time for preparations and extra food. We also have a booklet, Diabetes – Everyday Eating, which may also be useful. We hope that the newsletter and these two booklets will help to make le easier over the festive season.We are happy to send out these, free-of-charge, to any of your readersthey could contact InDependent Diabetes Trust by emailing email enquiries@iddtinternational.org or calling  .Jenny Hirst, co-chair, InDependent Diabetes Trust.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.The Courier continues to share more from the war diary written by Campbeltown soldier Gunner Neil MacLean after he became a prisoner of war following the st Highland Division’s surrender at St Valéry-en-Caux during the Second World War.The diary, and several photographs of Neil, during and after the war, were supplied by Neil’s son Calum, who knew nothing of the diary until after his father’s death.This week continues on from March :March # Weather cold and some heavy rain. On the th received  cigs from Jessie, out of smokes at the time. Gladly received.Started work at a Jewish cemetery taking out all the stones etc. Some of us came across coffins and some bodies not long in, so we refused to work there, but were told we did not need to go down so deep. About  of the men refused to go back and they were sent back to Schubin to XC . Finished that job and went to enlarge a sports ground for the school. Received a snap of Margaret on the th, it was very good.April # Weather very changeable. Received our Christmas parcels so on the th we had our Christmas dinner. A bit late, but better late than never. On th received a parcel of clothes from Connyglen, very acceptable.On the th we had a holiday and at night we had entertainment by some of the boys entitled #In Town Tonight#. It started with the news and then a running commentary of a football match, then on with #In Town Tonight# which lasted till bed time. It was very good. A few bottles of beer but did not have any.On th received about four marks for  francs I handed in at Schubin received from Captain Lewis. On the th they stopped us buying bread and on the th finished the job, there were rumours we were going back to Schubin.May # Weather very changeable and some snow. Started on the sports field we left off in . Spent my birthday here on a very cold day. th, received two parcels from  Longrow, lovely pair of boots. Very pleased to receive them. Had a bad foot, it was the boots that pulled my sinuses so I put on my new pair and all OK now.Received a new football so we had a few games on a Sunday, allowed out for an hour in the morning. By this time the sun was very warm and we had to work with our shirts off. Maybe lovely sunshine today and tomorrow would have snow. On the th had a very heavy fall of rain, so no work.June # st and nd a holiday so played football both days. Worked rd and th and heard we were moving out. Moved out next morning at am for the train. Had a good journey, only  in our truck.Saw some lovely girls on our way and Posen looks a lovely place, just passed through it. Landed at Gratz about .pm and walked about one and half hours with a heavy load on our back. Went to bed straight away. About , men in here.Lovely soup for dinner, had salt ling in soup and it was lovely. This is the best time we have had yet, plenty of smokes and eats and beds, hope it continues.Did not get long in this camp, spent one good night at a concert and one night at the boxing, very good. Church service on the Sunday.Before leaving here, we received two Red Cross Parcels each, but no smokes. Left Surdofon the th at am. Received one loaf each, travelled till am next morning in cattle trucks,  men in each truck very crowded.Continued in next week’s Courier.

were lted.Based at Aqualibrium, the club worked closely with Live Argyll to ensure that an organised, phasedwas put in place with the swimmers among the first in Scotland toto the water.Lockdown was particularly challenging for Kintyre ASC swimmers as nothing comes close to training in the same environment that they compete in but the club organised Zoom sessions with Live Argyll#s Jake Sanders and had regular online sessions as part of the Argyll and Clyde Swim Team.Swimmers stayed as active as they could in their own ways while ACST swimmers and coaches took part in a Q and A on Zoom with Scottish Olympic swimmer Hannah Miley.Club training has gradually increased and the club is almost back to where it was prior to lockdown with swimmers attending most sessions ‘pool ready’ to avoid using the changing rooms.Kintyre’s Evie Judge was again selected for Scottish Swimming’s District RegionalEvie had successfully qualied for the Scottish National Age Group Championshipsand was looking forward to swimming in Aberdeen when the pandemic hit and all events in the swimming calendar were cancelled.This year’s DRP programme was successfully held over Zoom with three sessions scheduled.Evie enjoyed this year#s experience although slightly dferent from the normal sessions usually held in Cumbernauld.She took part in group breakout sessions learning about aerobic and anaerobic speed training.In the final session she learned about the importance of ‘preparation’ and ‘visualisation’ as well as watching an excellent presentation by senior swimmer Katie Robertson followed by an informative Q and A discussion.Over recent training sessions the swimmers have been competing in this year’s Argyll and Clyde Championships virtually.Instead of swimmers travelling and meeting up at the same venue, which is not allowed under current restrictions, it was decided this year to hold the championships virtually.Clubs simply time swimmers in events at their own pool, present.#Kintyre ASC top squad swimmers have also been getting timed for Scottish Swimming’s Tighinn Comhla , a National Virtual Gathering.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.A report has revealed how the authority had hoped to consult with residents earlier this year on interest in helping to keep paths and pavements clear during the winter months.However, the consultation process was delayed due to Covid- and is now planned to take place during the summer and autumn of .The details were revealed in a report due to be considered by the council’s environment, development and infrastructure committee at a meeting via Skype on December .Executive director Kirsty Flanagan said: #The council previously allocated specic funds as part of the winter maintenance budget to support community engagement and resilience relating to winter maintenance.#To support the development of the scheme we are looking to run one pilot somewhere in Argyll and Bute with an established community group.#On-the-ground feedback from a pilot partner would provide further useful data to inform the roll-out.#Ms Flanagan listed ious criteria for community groups to become involved in the pilot, including that its work be undertaken on a reactive basis.However, it also adds that there should be no expectation by the council for the group to ‘turn out’ at any point, and that all PPE and equipment should be provided by the authority.Ms Flanagan added: #A review of the pilot scheme and the public consultation feedback will be brought back to a future committee in order to define the scheme and move towards a full roll-out across Argyll and Bute.#Should uptake be signicant the council may require to consider an area-based geographic criteria to ensure the limited fundingis prioritised where it will deliver the greatest benefit.#Neither a location nor a time for the pilot project have been identied, but it is aimed for a community resilience programme to be in place for winter  .

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Scotland’s nature agency has welcomed the designation of  Special Protection Areas , including the Sound of Gigha, and four Marine Protected Areasin Scotland’s seas.NatureScot, formerly Scottish Natural Heritage, says the announcement, made by Minister for Rural Affairs and Natural Environment Mairi Gougeon, gives additional protection to much-loved marine species, as well as  species of marine birds # such as great northern er, Slavonian grebe, long-tailed duck, Arctic tern and kittiwake # bringing the coverage of the Scottish MPA network to  per cent.Eileen Stuart, NatureScot’s interim director of nature and climate change, said: #The designation of these new sites sees some of our most iconic marine species # such as basking shark, minke whale and Risso’s dolphin # included in the MPA network as well as foraging areas for internationally important populations of seabirds, ers and sea ducks.#The Scottish MPA network now covers  per cent of our seas, marking signicant progress towards meeting global ambitions for marine conservation and ensuring a nature-rich future for Scotland, as well as offering locations where people can engage with and experience world-class wildle.#We are committed to working with others to ensure the MPA network and our wider seas are well-managed and monitored so that they can contribute to addressing the decline in nature, and help build resilience in the face of climate change.#In addition to the Sound of Gigha, the other new SPAs are: Solway Firth Seas off St Kilda Seas off Foula Outer Firth of Forth and St Andrews Bay Complex Moray Firth Ythan Estuary, Sands of Forvie and Meikle Loch Bluemull and Colgrave Sounds Coll and Tiree East Mainland Coast, Shetland West Coast of the Outer Hebrides Rum SPA .The four nature conservation MPAs are: North-east Lewis, Shiant East Bank, Sea of the Hebrides and Southern Trench.NatureScot undertook the site selection process based on the scientic evidence for the features in these MPAs and SPAs, presented this to stakeholders and provided formal advice to Marine Scotland.The nature agency provided guidance and advice to Marine Scotland and stakeholders on the conservation objectives and management advice for the MPAs and SPAs as part of its role, and supported Marine Scotland in the public consultation for these sites, including public events, stakeholder meetings.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.The Courier continues to share more from the previously unpublished prisoner of war diary written by Campbeltown soldier Gunner Neil MacLean who was captured following the st Highland Division’s surrender at St Valéry-en-Caux during the Second World War.The diary, and several photographs of Neil, during and after the war, were supplied by Neil’s son Calum, who knew nothing of the diary until after his father’s death.This week continues from June :June – Had a long walk to Willinberg XXB. Raining heavy. The usual standing about for hours then into billets  men in each small room. A rotten camp.The lice have started again. Dinners here not very good but luckily we have plenty RC tins with us. , British here,  French, some Poles, Belgium, etc. Hope we are not long in this dump.th, got registered at pm and then received a complete battledress and overcoat .Moved out of Willinberg XXB on the th, searched and then about one and a half hours walk to the station. Passed some lovely houses and through a large town, Aidenberg  Very nice.Landed at station.  men in cattle truck, wanted to put us in to  men but complained so they put us in with the passengers. With our new rig out on it just seemed we were going home on leave. Lovely scenery, short run.Arrived at our place about midnight and  men here before us. Our billet is in with a lot of German soldiers and we get what they have. Nice wooden beds, double deck, pillow, two blankets etc.Dinner very good and bread ration, one loaf between three, sausage and honey etc for tea. Very happy here for my first day. Four Campbeltown boys together. Settled down here now. All kinds of work from farming to labouring. Find the bread ration not plenty when working hard all day. Can#t buy bread, tobacco or anything like that. Word of us going back to our head camp.July – st, another  men arrived today. Makes the company up to  now. July th, another  men arrived. Hear we are moving out on Tuesday,  of us.Moved out on the th. We were ordered to split into two, they wanted to separate us but managed to get together. Four Campbeltown boys. Driven out in a horse wagon about  km and arrived at Louisenberg on a farm.Billeted in to two rooms on the farm. Received a good dinner. Meals for first week # breakfast am, one slice of bread am, one slice of bread and jam dinner, soup and buttermilk pm one and a half slices of bread tea, pm, potatoes and buttermilk.Working hours – up at .am, start am. One and a half hours for dinner and work till pm. Off all day on a Sunday. A very long working week at hay and hoeing. Having finished, we started cutting the harvest. Very poor, out three fields with reaper and fourth with binder.The guard we had was always chasing us up. Th – I could not stand him any longer and we had words, furious, he took his rle down and was going to give it to me in the rear end twice. The next day we had a change of guard, better than the first one.The end of July working hard. The food just so-so, always potatoes, waiting for Red Cross Parcelto come. The farmer stands over us most of the day.August – Half another month in, working away at the harvest and taking in thrashings. On the th we received a month’s supply of RCPs and did enjoy them. A big change from always potatoes.Our guard had to go away as his we was ill. A new one came in his place and seems very nice. Receiving our mail once a week now. It seems to be better that way.The end of August and nearly all the harvest in. The food has improved this month, maybe we noticed it with us having our RCP.Received our first pay here. RCP finished, waiting for next month’s issue to come. Not much mail lately, hope next month is better. Our [illegible] storks here left the farm this month. Was off work one and a half daywith a tummy ache.Continued in next week’s Courier.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Jura pays homage to George OrwellThe Isle of Jura is reviving the Jura Lodge as a writer#s retreat for one weekend only with a unique challenge in homage to George Orwell#s masterpiece .The author famously penned the novel on the island more than  years ago and the Jura community is offering writers the chance to follow in his footsteps.One budding author will win the chance to stay at the island#s exclusive Jura Lodge and compose a short story based on the island.However, they will only have , minutes to compose their story.To win the competition, writers are being asked to submit the first  words of the proposed short story. There are only two criteria: the narrative of the short story must take place on the island and the story should have a link to one of the many myths and legends about Jura.The finished product will be published on the Isle of Jura#s website.TWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOShip launch boost for CampbeltownAn estimated £, was pumped into the Kintyre economy last weekend with the naming of a new class of Stern trawler at Campbeltown shipyard.Around  guests travelled to Campbeltown for the naming of the latest addition to the fleet of Peterhead-based George Moodie and Sons Trawlers Ltd, Shemarah II.They came in coaches and occupied a large number of hotel rooms in and around Campbeltown.The . metre trawler was named by Mrs Jenner Moodie. It was the th addition to the family#s fleet she has named.Piper Derek Wilson of Kintyre District Pipe Band played a selection of tunes before the naming took place.Mr Douglas Moodie said at the naming: ‘She is lovely. We had a number of quotes from overseas to build her but we wanted to keep the work in Scotland.’Other guests at the naming included Sir William Lithgow and his we Lady Lithgow, Argyll and Bute MP Mrs Ray Michie, Argyll and Bute District Council chairman George McMillan and district Councillor Archie McCallum.FIFTY YEARS AGOUnique legal historyMaking his first appearance as a solicitor at Campbeltown Sherf Court on Friday was Mr Patrick Stewart, son of procurator fiscal, Mr A I B Stewart.Mr Stewart is the third generation to act as a solicitor in Campbeltown. His grandfather was Mr Archibald Stewart.Appearing with him was Mr John Mactaggart, son of Mr Charles Mactaggart. Mr Mactaggart is the fth generation in direct descent to work as a solicitor.There are older legal firms in Scotland than C and D Mactaggart, but none with a record of five generations in direct descent.Campbeltown is probably the only town in Scotland with such legal history. The stability of the legal profession in Scotland owes much to such family tradition.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOCampbeltownIn the gale of third December, a boat of the Campbeltown fishing fleet belonging to Mr James Wareham was totally lost at Lochranza.The crew had just discharged the cargo at the pier when the gale burst upon them. The sea was so heavy that the crew had to jump ashore for their lives and look helplessly at the boat being smashed to matchwood.The only salvage is the motor engine. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Kintyre and the Islands Councillor Alastair Redman made the claim after a report revealed that less than one in three street lighting repair jobs were completed within  days during the months from July to September.But Jim Smith, the authority’s head of roads and amenity services, said supplies for street lighting repairs were being restored.The discussion took place at a meeting of the council’s environment, development and infrastructure committee on Thursday December .According to the report, only  per cent of street lighting faults were fixed during those three summer months – against a target of  per cent.Councillor Redman told the meeting: #Our roads department was already between a rock and a hard place before Covid. We were short on resources and there were many things to fix.#I don’t mean to pile on at the time of a pandemic, but it does concern me theof time it is taking to fix street lighting.#Very often the answer from the roads department is that due to Covid or staffing, we won’t be able to have anybody look at the light for the next month.#I am a little concerned that Covid is a go-to answer now for everything.#Perhaps that is unfair, but I have concernsstreet lighting is not going to be looked at quicker.#Mr Smith responded: #I can give assurance that we are not using Covid as an excuse. There are glitches out there, and through the winter months street lighting repairs are more numerous than during the summer.#Provost David Kinniburgh then asked: #I know there are issues at the moment for street lights. Nothing is replaced because they are sourced from England, and because of Covid they were on furlough.#Do we have any update on when the supplier might be opening up again #Mr Smith answered: #There are supply challenges in numerous areas, but the demand remains the same, not just in the UK but across Europe as well.#The general position is that things are starting to trickle through and we are now receiving equipment that was not available before.#We have some lights to install in the Oban area which should have been with us a while ago. We have also had supply issues on things like parking meters.#So the short answer is that there remain some delays, and we are not in the position we were in pre-March to get things off the shelf, but it is beginning to improve.#Commentary in the report said: #Due to the team being signicantly reduced for a substantial period of time, the lighting team have been prioritising lighting repairs.#Actions are being taken to progress solutions to ensure the street lighting team have the resources necessary to carry out repairs.#The service plan on bringing in third party contractors to address the outages and communication is ongoing to address the more complex issues in order to get these resolved.#

title: musselburgh-swimmers-join-disability-sports-panel
story: Neil Ferguson, , and Samantha Louise Gough, , members of Musselburgh Amateur Swimming Club , have been appointed to the Scottish Disability SportYoung Persons Sport Panel.Joining a group of  other young people aged  to  from across Scotland, they will attend quarterly meetings and commit several hours each month to making a positive dference to disability sport in Scotland.Neil and Samantha will work alongside other young enthusiastic members and, with their knowledge and experience of disability sport, will help shape the future of disability sport in Scotland.The  enables young people with a disability to be heard and influence the planning and delivery of all aspects of Scottish Disability Sportrsquos work.The SDS Young Persons Sport Panel was established in late  with  members who have already made a massive contribution to disability sport in the last four years.Danny Kirkham, head coach at MASC, also known as Musselburgh Marlins, said: ldquoWe are delighted to hear that two of our MASC swimmers have been selected to sit on the  and we are immensely proud of this achievement and know they will represent themselves and Musselburgh ASC with distinction.ldquoNeil and Samantha are both hugely passionate, committed and enthusiastic iniduals who share a tremendous amount of knowledge and experience of disability sport and I am sure their impact will be a positive one for disability sport. Both swimmers have achieved their own sporting success in recent years and continue to compete and train at a very high level today.ldquoNeil is part of the Scottish para-swimming squad and regularly competes at competitions across the country. Samantha, having only recently started competing in swimming, has made tremendous progress and set a number of new personal best times.ldquoSamantha also competes in goalball at a British level and was recently awarded the Lothian Disability Sport Young Sports Person Award.ldquoThere is no doubt Neil and Samantha will be fantastic ambassadors for Scottish Disability Sport on the Young Persons Sport Panel and we are delighted they will have the opportunity to make a positive dference in disability sport in Scotland.ldquoBoth Neil and Samantha are passionate about doing their bit to encourage others with disabilities to seek opportunities, overcome obstacles and fulfil their own dreams.

title: covid-19-asymptomatic-testing-site-opens-queen-margaret-university
story: Funded by the UK Government, the testing site ndash for people showing no symptoms of coronavirus ndash is running in partnership with the university, Scottish Government and NHS Test and Protect to help students move home for the winter break and protect the wider community.It is hoped that testing ndash as well as limiting social mixing for two weeks before students go home ndash will help break the chain of transmission amongst students, especially when they are infected but are not aware of it, and help ensure the safety of their loved ones.The ATS will conduct lateral flow tests ndash rapid turnaround tests that can process samples on site without the need for laboratory equipment.The university is working with NHS Test  Protect to set up the on-campus ATS so that students who intend to move household over the winter break and are without symptoms, are able to get tested and asked to self-isolatethey test positive, or be quickly reassuredthey do not.Sir Paul Grice, the universityrsquos principal, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be able to offer this facility.ldquoWhile many of our students will remain in Edinburgh and East Lothian, we know that many others are planning to change household or to visit family and friends over the winter break.ldquoBy participating in testing, they will help avoid the spread of Covid to their family, friends and the wider community.Testing is available for all students. title: hayley-cohen-become-east-lothians-youngest-church-minister
story: The Rev Cohen ndash the countyrsquos youngest minister and the seventh youngest in Scotland ndash wasordainedat Northesk Parish Church, Musselburgh, on Thursday evening.Originally from New Jersey in the USA, she is looking forward to her first charge after falling in love with Scotland as a student.She succeeds the Rev Alison MacDonald, who is now minister at St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington.Ms Cohen ndash who describes herself as ldquopretty outgoing and extroverted ndash first came to Scotland as a study-abroad student in  at the University of Edinburgh.She said: ldquoI quickly fell in love with Scotland and knew that I wanted toas soon as I could when my year at Edinburgh was over.ldquoDuring that year, I met my now husband, Ross , while we were both studying theology at New College. Ross is originally from outside Lancaster, England.ldquoI ed to Scotland in  after completing my BA in the US to spend a year working for Balerno Parish Church as their parish assistant. This was a fantastic year and really gave me a taste of the le of the parish minister in Scotland.She ed to the US in  and studied for her Masters of Divinity at Princeton Theological Seminary, and began training for ministry in the Presbyterian Church .After graduating with her Masters in , she went to work in Jerusalem for an ecumenical institute that ran educational pilgrimages and sabbatical programmes.She married Ross in Edinburgh and the couple moved to Durham, where Ross was working towards his PhD, and Ms Cohen applied to transfer into the Church of Scotland.She said: ldquoThis decision to transfer was an easy one for me to make given my love of Scotland, my experience working in a Church of Scotland parish through my time in Balerno and the long-standing relationship between the Presbyterian Churchand Church of Scotland.ldquoMy transfer was accepted and I went on placement at St Andrewrsquos Clermiston in Edinburgh under the supervision of the Rev Alistair Keil, who Irsquom delighted will be preaching at my ordination. I was with St Andrewrsquos until October.ldquoI was approved to begin applying for my first charge just as the UK was entering lockdown in March.ldquoIt was clear there wasnrsquot going to be anything normal about the process of looking for a church.ldquoBut Northesk was actually the first parish profile on the Church of Scotland website at which I looked.ldquoI was moved by their expression of care for their ministers. Northesk has had five ministers in the last  years I will be the sixth. To me, this is an indicator that ministers are made to feel very much welcome and at home in Northesk.ldquoWhen I began to meet members of the congregation through interviews, first online and then in person, it was clear they were incredibly friendly and welcoming people willing to get stuck in and do the work that needs doing for love of God, their church, and their community.She added: ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to becoming the minister of Northesk and I am particularly excited to meet the people of Fisherrow and Musselburgh, whether they are churchgoers or not.ldquoIrsquom from the US, so Irsquom pretty outgoing and extroverted. I like listening to people and hearing their stories. If anyone sees me in the street, please stop me, introduce yourself, and say hello. Irsquod be delighted to meet you.ldquoMy plans for the church will be made in conversation with the congregation after spending time with them and listening to where they have been, where they are now, and where they want to go. We know there is a lot of work to do but I am personally very excited for the possibilities that are before us.ldquoRight now, wersquore looking forward to the season of Advent and Christmas. I know things will feel very dferent this year at Christmas because of the pandemic but Irsquom hoping that Northesk can continue to be a place where people can come and celebrate joy and the hope of the birth of Jesus, whether at home or in person.In her free time, Ms Cohen enjoys bird-watching and is delighted to be so close to Levenhall Links.She said: ldquoI enjoy walking with my husband. We love exploring new places together.ldquoIrsquom a keen home cook, singer, painter, yoga practitioner and an all-round nature lover.Northesk sold the old manse on New Street and the couple live in the new manse near Pinkie.Simon Fairnie, on behalf of Northesk Church, said: ldquoThe congregation are delighted at the appointment of, and welcome, their new, young minister. She will be a lsquofresh startrsquo for Northesk Church and its parish.

title: pupils-try-new-hire-bikes-musselburghs-electric-bridge
story: They were joined by Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Councilrsquos environment spokesperson, who paid the bridge a visit last week.The bridge, which crosses the River Esk, has been acquired by the council and opened for use ndashinitially by cyclists.However, requests from groups managing public events will be considered regarding potential alternative uses of the bridge, including vehicle traffic.Mr Hampshire, said: ldquoFollowing successful negotiations with ScottishPower, the former owner of the bridge, East Lothian Council undertook a structural survey and carried out some repairs to the bridge. As part of the Spaces for People programme, we are delighted to have been able to procure the bridge and open it up for active travel.ldquoWe know that during this pandemic, people have been seeking more opportunities for active travel in our local communities, including an increase in cycling.ldquoLocal residents who are keen to try out cycling but donrsquot currently have a bike can now hire one from the two Just Eat cycle hire sites recently installed in the town.ldquoThere are further exciting proposals around sustainable travel planned for Musselburgh, including a trial transport lsquomulti-hubrsquo and a wide public consultation considering future options, including new walking and cycling routes.The bridge was built in the s to provide access for construction traffic involved in the building of Cockenzie Power Station and became known as the Electric Bridge. In recent years, it has been closed for all access and only opening in response to public events in Musselburgh, including race days at Musselburgh Racecourse and the Edinburgh Marathon.Signage has been put in place to promote the bridge as a main access route for cyclists, with the neighbouring footbridge for pedestrian use.

title: uncertain-future-eyesore-exercise-stations-river-tyne-haddington
story: A series of lsquoexercise stationsrsquo were installed along the path next to the River Tyne nearly five years ago.Ten stations ndash a series of basic metal structures ndash were created, stretching from The Maltings to The Sands, funded by the townrsquos community council, Paths For All and Ageing Well.At the time, members of Haddingtonrsquos community council questioned how much the exercise stations would be used.The condition and future of the scheme were again questioned at a meeting of the group last month.Fiona McEwan, secretary, asked: ldquoWhatrsquos happening  Because it is a blooming mess.ldquoAll we are left with at the moment are poles. People are going to say: lsquoWhat on earth is this rsquoldquoIt is an eyesore ndash either get rid of it or do something with it.Each station along the route is supposed to have an A sign, with a picture and text explaining how a person should use the equipment.Shortly after they were launched, they were described as ldquoabsurd and ldquougly, as well as ldquodefacing the natural beauty of the landscape.A sheet of paper was tied to a tree near the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre urging members of the public to contact East Lothian Council to see the ldquoill-judged project removed.Councillor Tom Trotter, Haddington and Lammermuir ward member, was among those attending the virtual meeting.He acknowledged that the scheme had been questioned when it was put in place and said: ldquoThey raised some eyebrows when they were put in.ldquoThey were put in with the best of intentions but I have only ever seen somebody stretching once.When community councillors approved the scheme, members were told there would be four display boards explaining the purpose of the route, which would be maintained by the local authority.Community councillor Graham Samuel also wonderedthe project had a future. He said: ldquoThe message board had been replaced.ldquoThe original was graffitied and they then came along and stuck a sticker over the top of it but it has now been pulled off.ldquoThe main sign that is at Neilson Park as you come in, and was meant to show where you are, itrsquos like someone has taken a hammer to it.ldquoThe perspex is broken and the graphic is falling apart.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed the scheme was being examined. She said: ldquoWe are arranging assessment of the exercise stations and will determine appropriate actions thereafter, which we will be able to advise to the community council accordingly.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-supporting-need-christmas
story: One of the appeals has seen the school organise its annual lsquoreverse Advent calendarrsquo.Typically, Advent calendars see people open one door a day in the countdown to Christmas Day and title: major-refurbishment-archerfield-walled-garden-go-ahead-new-year
story: The long-awaited work is due to start in the New Year, with doors closing on January  and set to reopen on an as-yet-unconfirmed date in the spring.The plans will see a garden shop and retail space created in the area formerly occupied by Knops Brewery, which closed at the beginning of this year.The shop will sell indoor and outdoor plants, as well as other garden tools and equipment.The focus on a garden theme will be carried into the cafe, whose kitchen team will be led by new chef Duncan Adamson.Duncan has worked in Michelin star kitchens and will focus on using the produce grown in the walled garden itself, working with gardeners throughout the year to create seasonal menus.In addition, the cafe will move to a self-service model and will feature a salad servery and pre-prepared sandwiches and rolls.The playpark space at the rear of the building will also have a canopy installed over part of it, with additional seating, to allow all-weather outdoor dining.A spokesperson for Archerfield Walled Garden said of the upcoming refurbishment: ldquoItrsquos long awaited and wersquore very excited about it.ldquoThe garden shop and retail space will be pretty sizeable, about a third of the floor space of the building.ldquoOur food offering is going to be quite dferent to what wersquore doing at the moment itrsquos going to be a lot more focused on the garden-to-plate ethos.ldquoWe really want to become a destination for foods.ldquoWersquove obviously got the beautul outdoor space and the gardens but we really want to attract people because they think itrsquos a great cafe and we serve amazing food.Ross McGregor, director of operations for Archerfield Estates Limited, had told the Courier in January this year: ldquoThe business has been growing over the last few years and now we are adding to that.ldquoWe aim to make it slicker for the customer, as well as a simpler and more beautul place.

title: ancient-egyptian-artefacts-display-haddingtons-john-gray-centre
story: The exhibition aims to reveal how Ancient Egypt has captivated Scotland over the past  years.Called lsquoDiscovering Ancient Egyptrsquo, it is on display until April  the curator is Dr Daniel Potter, assistant curator at National Museums Scotland.It is a National Museums Scotland touring exhibition that will examine Scotlandrsquos contribution to Egyptology through the lives of three people, whose work in the field helped improve the understanding of Ancient Egyptian culture.The first is archaeologist Alexander Henry Rhind born in Wick, he was the first archaeologist to work in Egypt.On display will be objects from a tomb he excavated, including a lsquoBook of the Deadrsquo papyrus and inscribed wooden labels that were found with the mummied remains of  princesses who all shared the same royal tomb.Also featured is Edinburgh-based astronomer Charles Piazzi Smyth, who carried out the first largely accurate survey of the Great Pyramid and took the first photographs of its interior. Some of the instruments he used will be on display, including a measuring rod.The third person is Aberdonian Annie Pirie Quibell, an artist who was one of the first women to study Egyptology and who went on to work on signicant excavations as both an artist and archaeologist.She studied and excavated with W M Flinders Petrie, often described as the lsquofather of Egyptian archaeologyrsquo.Her artistic skills recorded the site and artefacts she found.One of the pieces on display is pieces more than , years old, from a find at one of the earliest temple sites.The Haddington museum is following all of the appropriate Government and health guidelines and people are recommended to book their visit beforehand admission is free. Call   or email elms@eastlothian.gov.ukIt is open Wednesdays to Fridays, am-pm and -pm, last entry .pm it is closed December  to January .John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesperson for economic development and tourism, said: ldquoAttracting a national exhibition to East Lothian reflects both the ability and professionalism of our museums staff.ldquoThis year has been a very challenging year for us all but this exhibition provides an opportunity locally for residents and families to enjoy which, when combined with a visit to the High Street shops, cafes and other hospitality venues, can provide a welcome day out.

title: 500-000-alterations-dunbars-bayswell-park-hotel-approved
story: A new -cover restaurant and lounge bar is planned for the Bayswell Park Hotel.Other alterations to the hotel, which dates back more than  years, include the installation of a lt and accessible toilet.Two new hot tub suites will also be created within a second-floor extension, while four single rooms will be converted into double rooms and improvements will be carried out in the car park.Fourteen objections were lodged with East Lothian Council, with concerns including that the alterations and extensions would have ldquoan adverse impact on the character of the neighbourhood due to the ldquosize, scale, heights, designs and materials.A supporting statement included with the planning application had noted the importance of the scheme to the businessrsquos future.It read: ldquoThe existing business model is barely sustainable, and the overarching objective of the development is to invest c.pound, in infrastructure improvements to improve the future prospects of the hotel.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the Dunbar and East Linton ward, felt the planned investment was good news for the town.He said: ldquoIt is an important hotel within Dunbar.ldquoAny investment in that business to give it a future has got to be welcomed by everybody.ldquoIt is one of the bigger hotels that we have. The better the quality of it, the more chance the business has got of survival because the trade is really, really dficult just now.ldquoIrsquom hoping now they have got consent that they move quickly to make that investment to upgrade the hotel to the highest standard they possibly can.A prior planning application highlighted the now-approved plans plus a bid to see a new building created between the hotel and the clftops. However, that was withdrawn, with the application split into two separate proposals ndash although the second application with the proposed hot tub building is yet to be considered by East Lothian Council.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoIf we are serious about tourists coming to the town, then we need a whole range of accommodation and we have got to welcome investment in hotels in the town.The townrsquos community council was asked for its views on the Bayswell Park Hotelrsquos proposals.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoDunbar Community Council, as a consultee to this planning application, state that there is support for a quality hotel experience within the town.ldquoThus, there is some support for the proposed investment by the owner in the hotel, particularly with regards to the proposed upgrade of the lt and the renovation of some rooms within the building.ldquoThe proposals for the extensions are considered to be an improvement on the previous application.ldquoHowever, they state that there remains concern regarding the scale of the ground-floor extension and the large glass windows to be formed within it.

title: retired-musselburgh-journalist-george-campbell-cunningham-publishes-first-book
story: George Campbell Cunningham, , of Greenfield Park, Monktonhall, is a former convener of Tyne and Esk Writers, and features an ldquoeclectic mix of  short stories in his publication Her Holiness The Pope.He said: ldquoSome are slightly thought-provoking while others have a sting in the tail others are simply funny.Mr Cunningham said: ldquoI was idly scrolling through some computer files one day when I came across a couple of short stories I had written some time ago and forgotten about, so I set about finding how many others there were.ldquoSome were only half written, other were just outline ideas and most needed a complete re-write.ldquoSo I set about editing and in some cases just taking the theme and producing a new version.Although fictional, some of the stories are set in real historical events.Mr Cunningham, a former pupil of the Royal High School in Edinburgh, said his stories ranged ldquofrom seeing great events through the eyes of those who were there to antics in a government press office that brings central London grinding to a halt, adding: ldquoOne story records the exchange between a husband and we at a funeral tea and raises, in a humorous way, whether a flat cap is a bunnet or a hat!ldquoAt one time, there were a number of magazines on bookstalls made up of short stories and were ideal for people who were commuting. In some small way, I hope this book helps fill the gap.Mr Cunningham has always wanted to write from an early age and went on to become a trainee journalist on the Scottish .He said: ldquoI was brought up in a family that enjoyed reading books so that became my inspiration.ldquoI became a journalist thinking that might be the route to writing novels ndash but I was wrong. Thinking like a journalist does not really make creative writing easy.ldquoTo help me make the transition, I joined the Musselburgh group of Tyne and Esk Writers and that became my launch pad to creative writing.ldquoAlthough I left school with no real qualications, I discovered early in my association that Glasgow University ran a Master of Letters degree course by distanced learning and, on the basis of my CV and samples of my writing, I was admitted to the course ndash all thanks to Tyne and Esk Writers.He added: ldquoAs the world of newspapers began to shrink, I joined the Government Information Servicein Edinburgh, ending my association with the GIS as a spokesman for the Royal Air Force in Scotland.ldquoI then ventured into the world of commercial PR, eventually setting up on my own. I loved digging out offbeat articles for my clientsrsquo activities.ldquoFor me, observation is an essential skill for anyone wanting to be a creative writer ndash along, of course, with a vivid imagination.For more information and to order a signed copy, send your details to stillwriting now@gmail

title: musselburgh-couple-brought-together-love-rock-roll-celebrate-diamond-wedding-anniversary
story: The couple, from Musselburgh, have been ldquooverwhelmed by the kindness from well-wishers who sent cards to mark their diamond wedding.The icing on the cake was a card from the Queen which will be put in an anniversary frame, which they received as a gt, and have pride of place on the wall of their home on Galt Road.Andrew, , known as Drew, and Marica, , were born and brought up in Musselburgh.They met at the local dancing that was on every Saturday evening at Stoneyhill Community Centre.Both shared a love of rock and roll, and loved to jive together.Their relationship blossomed and they were married at Loretto Chapel on Newbigging, on November , .Drew, an apprentice joiner, was  and Marica, a wig maker, was  when they tied the knot.The couple started married le together staying at Drewrsquos grandmotherrsquos home on Eskview Road, Musselburgh. They lived there for a few months before moving into their own home on the townrsquos Campie Road.The couple have four children ndash Gillian, Ian, Paula and Mark. They are now , ,  and  years old.Drew and Marica now have six granddaughters, seven great grandchildren, and their first great, great grandchild arrived in March.The family have been through a dficult year, as Drew was taken into hospital on March  and tested positive for Covid-. He ed home on May .Daughter Gillian said: ldquoIt was an extremely worrying time for the whole family indeed. Dad is now making good progress in his recovery.ldquoSadly, all the family couldnrsquot enjoy their special day with them due to Covid restrictions but hope still to go ahead with a big family lunch next year to celebrate.The couple said the main crux of their long and happy marriage was that ldquono matter what happens in le,you work through it together and have love for each other and around you, thatrsquos all that matters.ldquoLove conquers all! they stressed.Gillian added: ldquoMum and dad are truly our king and queen of our family and we couldnrsquot be prouder of them both.

title: young-peoples-support-group-heavy-sound-raising-5-000-christmas-campaign
story: Heavy Sound, a community interest company, works with those aged  to  who are not engaged with the education system or who are in care and have been referred by Childrenrsquos Hearings Scotland.The youngsters might be struggling with the education system or live in a traumatic household with parents who cannot look after themselves or their children.Heavy Sound, launched by Jordan Butler, who himself experienced extreme hardship as a teenager, runs music and sports projects to teach skills and build confidence.A spokeswoman for Heavy Sound said: ldquoWe get referrals through social work and through education systems, the high schools.ldquoWersquove got computers, a skills lab where people can do all sorts of learning ndash arithmetic and writing -- talk about education and jobs, but we also have a huge space which wersquove turned into a gym, and we have a recording studio.A typical day with the group, which moved from its office in Tranent to Cockenzie Business Hub, might see a teenager learning the martial art Muay Thai in the gym having a one-to-one discussion with a coach on fitness, healthy eating and avoiding conflict and taking part in a music session DJing, writing lyrics and producing tracks on state-of-the-art recording equipment.Throughout the day, youngsters also have the opportunity to take part in their choice of activities, including bike maintenance, bike rides and creative arts such as expressive art spray painting.The group also operates the Community Reach  Inclusion Bus , a single-decker bus which has been turned into a mobile recording studio and music lab, and visits schools and areas of deprivation.During lockdown, when young people were unable to join the group projects, Heavy Sound delivered , weekly food parcels, made  bulk community kitchen deliveries and , shopping deliveries, and distributed , lunch bags and meals throughout East Lothian and Edinburgh.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe total cost of funding a young personrsquos day at Heavy Sound is pound..ldquoOur hope is that, by raising pound,, we will enable another  sessions to be experienced by those who need it the most.ldquoOur work highlights the fact that having one positive and trusted relationship in a young personrsquos le can be all they need to go on and achieve what might seem like the impossible.To donate to the Heavy Sound Christmas fund, title: new-book-celebrates-life-legendary-tranent-activist-jackie-crookston
story: Jackie Crookston, who was born in Old Kirk, Gladsmuir, in , was one of many women throughout the nation who was outraged by the Scottish Militia Act, which saw the Westminster government conscript able-bodied Scottish men between the ages of  and  into military service.Crookston is said to have organised protest marches, beating a drum to intimidate the soldiers who came to Tranent to pick up the conscriptees.She was one of at least  people killed in the massacre that followed. A statue commemorating Crookston was unveiled in Tranentrsquos Civic Square in .She now features in Feisty and Fiery and Fierce, a follow-up to Mairirsquos book Warriors and Witches and Damn Rebel Bitches.Mairi, head of literature, languages and publishing at Creative Scotland, is due to take up the post of CEO at Seven Stories, the National Centre for Childrenrsquos Books in Newcastle, next year.The author, who lives in Portobello, said: ldquoWomen are almost never memorialised in the way that men have been in the form of statues and the naming of buildings or great civic squares.ldquoJackie interested me partly because there is a statue ndash three cheers for the good folk of Tranent for putting up a statue to a named woman.ldquoMy mum and dad live in Musselburgh and I should have known about Jackie but I didnrsquot.ldquoIt was my mum, who was a history teacher until she retired, who told me about Jackie and I absolutely loved the idea that there was an example we could have in the book of a woman who has been commemorated.ldquoBut, of course, we donrsquot know an awful lot about her ndash all of it is in oral tradition. But often you do have to look to oral traditions for womenrsquos stories because history is controlled by those who write it, and womenrsquos words were so rarely recorded.ldquoJackie was a brave woman. She marched for justice, quite literally banging her drum, and she died for that. She stood up to authority and all its wrongdoings, and is a great example to us.The story of Crookston and the massacre also features in East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskillrsquos recent book, Radical Scotland: Uncovering Scotlandrsquos radical history ndash from the French Revolutionary era to the  Rising.Also highlighted in Feisty and Fiery and Fierce is Agnes Campbell, a printer who lived in Edinburgh but whose business prowess in the th century saw the proleration of paper mills along East Lothianrsquos River Esk.Mairi said: ldquoAgnes is the reason that paper milling was established on the Esk she inherited her husbandrsquos printing business in the s when he died and she remarried but at that point married women couldnrsquot transact business in their own name, so she obtained an act of parliament to allow her to transact business.ldquoShe was then able to control a fortune she would otherwise have lost. And shersquos the person who essentially established paper milling on the Esk.Feisty and Fiery and Fierce, published by Black  White, is available to buy online.

title: north-berwicks-sandy-wallace-runs-70km-celebrate-70th-birthday
story: Sandy Wallace, a retired civil engineer, is a regular runner and goes on a daily jog around North Berwick.He said: ldquoI ran right through lockdown and enjoyed it, and I didnrsquot have the pressure of races, which I usually do a lot of.And in celebration of his landmark birthday on November , he decided to run a km route around East Lothian: one kilometre for every year of his le.He left his house on Macnair Avenue at am, heading west towards Cockenzie, turning back towards Longniddry and then running along the railway walk to Haddington.The mostly off-road route continued along the River Tyne walkway to East Linton before he joined the John Muir Way back to North Berwick.Friends and fellow members of Haddington Running Club joined him for sections of the run, which Sandy said was a huge help in taking his mind off the task thanks to the chatter and encouragement.One of his two grandsons, Jamie Wallace, also joined him for some of the miles and it is hoped he will make the run a family tradition of sorts in the future.Sandy finished his -mile run in seven hours and  minutes, ing to cheering family and neighbours. . . and a well-deserved birthday cake.He said he was surprised at the number of people who came out to support him and cheer him on at the finish line.Sandy was supported throughout the challenge by we Claire who, from her car, provided food, drink and encouraging words. She also co-ordinated with those who joined Sandy along the way.When asked why he decided to take on the challenge, Sandy said: ldquoIt was a challenge to show that age is not a barrier to achieving goals of physical endurance.Being a former marathon runner ndash having run  in his letime ndash helped prepare Sandy for the challenge.He also ran increasingly longer distances over the three-month period before the big day.Sandy has now thrown down the challenge to others to match his feat.He said: ldquoI enjoyed the challenge and am delighted to have finished it.ldquoIt went better than I thought it would. It wasnrsquot easy but it wasnrsquot hard either. I was a bit weary at the end, though.He praised East Lothian Council for providing the walkways through the countyrsquos picturesque countryside and encouraged others to get out and try these paths, perhaps without running the whole distance.Sandy said: ldquoThe John Muir Way, riverside walk and railway walk are fabulous to run and show the area at its best.ldquoFor runners, there are endless opportunities to get out along any of the safe off-road sections without having to go to the s I have.Running friend and Haddington sports shop owner Joe Forte said: ldquoThis was an inspired achievement by Sandy, who has been running for  years. He just goes on and on and there is no telling what his next challenge will be.Sandy is now enjoying a well-earned rest and is looking forward to running races next year when Covid restrictions are eased.

title: departing-north-berwick-community-council-member-sue-northrop-praised
story: Sue Northrop was the grouprsquos single point of contactthroughout her term and played an important part during the Beast from the East snowstorm in  and the coronavirus lockdown this spring.During lockdown, she led a sub-group of the community council which operated its action plan and oversaw the resilience effort and the volunteers who helped people across North Berwick.Volunteers helped collect prescriptions, deliver shopping and cook meals, with hundreds of copies of the Courier bought and delivered, and a Street Links scheme set up that linked neighbours together.However, Sue felt she had ldquodone her bit and she has now chosen to step down from the community council and her role as SPoC.Elected four years ago and sitting on the community council for one term, Sue has lived in North Berwick for the past  years.A qualied yoga teacher, she is also a member of the North Berwick Community Centre management committee, chair of Carers Scotlandrsquos advisory committee, and a member of Marie Curiersquos Scottish advisory board.Sue obtained undergraduate and doctorate degrees in psychology at the University of St Andrews and completed a masters in dementia studies at the University of Stirling. She has previously worked for the Scottish Government, the University of Stirling and in local government.After caring for family members with dementia for more than  years, she set up Dementia Friendly East Lothianin  and now works across the county and beyond to help make communities more inclusive and supportive of people living with dementia.She also works collaboratively to improve services and organises friendship groups and events for those affected by dementia.Judy Lockhart, chair of North Berwick Community Council , said: ldquoDuring her tenure, Sue has made a huge impact on NBCC as well as her efforts for the town.ldquoSue has a passion for care and helping elderly people in particular, and time and time again has ensured that decisions we make as NBCC consider the impact on this group.ldquoOn behalf of NBCC, I would like to thank Sue for her service. You will be sorely missed by us all, although I very much hope that from time to time we can continue to work with you in support of DFEL.ldquoIf there is one thing that I have personally learned from Sue, it is never to be afraid to be the only person in the room with a dferent view. Without that dfering view, the outcome will likely not be anywhere near as successful as it could have been.Community councillor Ian Watson replaced Sue as SPoC.The community council is now on the lookout for two more members.Those who are aged over , live, work or own lease property in the town or have been registered as a local government elector for the last  months and are interested in becoming a member should contact secretary Kathryn Smith at secretary@northberwickcommunitycouncil.org.uk

title: wear-makes-feel-good-day-compass-school-success
story: Youngsters at The Compass School swapped unorms for a lsquoWear what makes you feel good dayrsquo on November .Everyone taking part wore clothes that made them feel positive, with a wide range of outfits on display.Superhero costumes, sports kits, smart suits and stylish dresses were all worn, with everyone, including parents and staff, making a donation to the charity.Mark Becher, headteacher at the school, on the townrsquos West Road, was delighted with the response.He said: ldquoOn what was World Kindness Day, our families and friends have been extremely generous in supporting Children in Need and the many causes across the country it supports.ldquoGiven the gloom and despondency of the current year, the pupil council wished to have a day where children and staff could celebrate what makes them happy and consequently we had a very colourful and vibrant lsquofeel-goodrsquo day at school.ldquoWe have once again been amazed by the generosity of our families and friends and we are so pleased that we have been able to raise such a signicant amount for this important charity and support the tremendous work with children that it enables across the country.

title: darren-eales-gets-eight-year-sport-ban-second-doping-violation
story: UK Anti-Dopingcollected an in-competition urine sample from Darren Eales on February , , after a match between his Prestonpans-based team Preston Lodge and Dumfries Saints.Analysis of Mr Ealesrsquo A sample ed an adverse analytical findingfor stanozolol, an anabolic steroid that is derived from testosterone. The drug is used to enhance performance and is prohibited from sport at all times under the  WADA Prohibited List.Speaking on the case, Pat Myhill, UKADrsquos director of operations, said: ldquoThe decision to ban Mr Eales from sport for eight years shows the serious consequences of repeated attempts to cheat."The World Anti-Doping Code provides longer bans for second offences and this is a clear message that repeated cheating will not be tolerated.A UKAD statement said: "The case was referred by UKAD to the National Anti-Doping Panelin July last year."After affording Mr Eales numerous extensions, the NADP eventually imposed an eight-year ban last month after determining the case on the papers."Mr Eales did not provide any evidence to very his claim that he had used a contaminated supplement."Taking into consideration his provisional suspension, Mr Eales ban started on February , , and will expire at midnight on February , ."A Scottish Rugby spokesperson said: ldquoScottish Rugby takes a zero-tolerance approach to any use of prohibited substances to enhance performance."Theof this sanction, at eight years for a second doping offence, is welcomed as a warning to others and ensures Mr Eales will not be able to play rugby again until .ldquoEven though the playing season across Scotland has been curtailed by the Covid- pandemic, there is still the same anti-doping policies and measures in place, and we encourage any feedback from within the rugby communitythere is suspicion of anyone using illegal products.

title: s5-s6-pupils-county-high-school-work-home
story: Late last week it was confirmed that a small number of people from Musselburgh Grammar School had tested positive for coronavirus, resulting in those in close contact with these iniduals also being asked to self-isolate.A high percentage of those self-isolating are S and S students and it has also been confirmed that the school has a "situation where fewer than normal teaching staff will be in school during the week ahead".These factors have led to parents and carers being contacted this afternoon to ask that all fth and sixth year pupils should work from home for a week from tomorrow .The letter said: "We appreciate that this decision may be frustrating and inconvenient, however, we believe it is the right decision in the interests of everyonersquos health and safety and to ensure that we can continue to provide continued education for our students, which is always our top priority."We believe that this temporary measure of introducing blended learning for one week is the most effective and productive solution for all S and S students in the week ahead."It avoids a situation where teaching resources are split between working with limited numbers of students in school and those who are self-isolating. It means we will be able to deliver a consistent quality of learning experience for all S and S students via remote learning."We want to reassure parents that appropriate tasks and assignments will be readily available for Sstudents from Monday via Google Classroom.: New Covid case at North Berwick High School"Any student who does not have a device to access the work should contact [depute headteacher] Ms Craigie at the school on Monday morning and the school will provide a device."[Headteacher] Mr Gerrie will be writing separately to S and S families with further information. As you are already aware, we have developed remote blended learning as a contingency, should it be required."This action will also help us to minimise transmission of the virus and help protect younger students, who should continue to attend schoolthey remain well and have no symptoms of Covid-."Students in S- are to attend school as normal.

title: we-shouldnt-live-slugs-living-room
story: Rebecca McFadden says she was promised a move out of her council house in Haddington after months of living with the slugs but nothing has been done.Now her GP has written to East Lothian Council to confirm mum-of-two Rebecca, , is being treated for agoraphobia and social anxiety brought on by living in the house.Her doctor added that concern about the slugs in her living room ldquowhere her children play has caused ldquoworsening anxiety and panic symptoms.Rebecca moved into the house on Abbots View two years ago after giving birth to her oldest child Evie however, it quickly became clear there were problems.She said: ldquoFamily commented that our clothes smelled of damp ndash it was in the house and permeating our clothes.ldquoI called the council but there were no obvious signs of damp on the walls so they said there wasnrsquot a problem. Then the slugs started appearing.%imageRebecca was horried to find slugs in her living room and on her curtains. Silvery trails left by the creatures covered the childrenrsquos toys and carpets.She said: ldquoThe slugs are horric and I am terried they will cause a health problem for the children.ldquoJamie [her son] was born premature and has some respiratory issues so I am constantly worried about the impact living here is having on him.ldquoI donrsquot seem to be able to get anywhere with the council and I worry all the time.ldquoMy self-esteem has been affected because I worry our clothes smell of damp. Irsquove been diagnosed with agoraphobia and have anxiety attacks.ldquoIt is a living nightmare.Rebecca said that when lockdown began she was told her family would be moved to a new home but she says she has heard nothing since.She said: ldquoWe shouldnrsquot have to live like this, it is appalling.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoFor reasons of confidentiality, we cannot comment in detail on inidual cases.ldquoAny complaints about problems with damp or infestations are always dealt with swtly.ldquoPest control experts are called in when necessary.ldquoSome property maintenance work was delayed due to lockdown restrictions earlier in the year however, inspections and repair work resumed as soon as home visits were allowed.ldquoIn cases where a move to a dferent property is deemed the best course of action, we support tenants but, due to an extremely high demand for council homes, it can take some time before a suitable property becomes available.

title: man-pushed-woman-onto-hotel-bed-grabbed-neck
story: Ross Currie, of Castle Street, assaulted the woman by seizing her by the neck at the Hampton by Hilton hotel in the cityrsquos Fountainbridge.Currie uttered threats of violence before he pushed the woman onto a bed within a room at the hotel and began to restrict her breathing.He also placed a piece of clothing around her neck and restricted her breathing, all to the womanrsquos injury, at the Capital hotel on October .Currie admitted the attack on November  at Edinburgh Sherf Court and he was back in the dock for sentencing last Friday.Lawyer Phil Moore said that -year-old Currie had committed ldquoa serious offence but he has shown remorse.Sherf Adrian Cottam said: ldquoIt could have resulted in tragic consequences easily, even though Irsquom sure you didnrsquot mean that. Grabbing someone by the neck could result in death more easily than people think.ldquoUnpaid work is probably the most appropriate way of dealing with this. The report is favourable.Currie was sentenced to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community over the next  months.
