title: msp-column-best-worlds-argument
story: It was Mackintoshrsquos leadership, ably assisted by East Lothian Labour Party, that helped lead Scottish Labour towards support for a devolved Parliament and eventually to its delivery in .His words are carved into Parliament: ldquoPeople in Scotland want a degree of government for themselves. It is not beyond the wit of man to devise the institutions to meet these demands.The annual memorial lecture has been a fitting way of preserving his legacy. As a member of the lecture committee since , I have been very proud of the quality of speakers we have welcomed over the years.This yearrsquos lecture was due to take placetodaywith Sir Keir Starmer but has unfortunately had to be postponed for the moment. He plans to talk about the next phase of devolution and how it can work for Scotland and the rest of the UK. This is an important and timely debate.It is important to highlight that the constitutional question need not be binary ndash either the break-up of the UK offered by the SNP or the outdated centralisation of the Tories ndash but can instead focus on how we maximise the benefits of both devolution and Scotlandrsquos important role within the UK.The pandemic has shown how powerful devolution is, with Scotland controlling our public health response but still part of the economic response such as lsquofurloughrsquo made possible by the resources of the whole UK.This lsquobest of both worldsrsquo argument was at the heart of the pro-UK, pro-devolution message in  and I believe it still broadly reflects the view of the majority here in East Lothian.

title: mp-column-grim-impact-brexit
story: Hard-working and good company, their English was impeccable and I learned not to assume all migrants from that part of the world are Polish. One was Hungarian and the other Czech, which explained why theyrsquod be speaking English between themselves and not just as a courtesy to me. Both are settled here and onersquos now married to a Scottish lass.I couldnrsquot help thinking of them when I heard the Home Secretary boast of her actions in ending free movement. These two lads, along with countless others, have come here and made this their home. Theyrsquove added to our communities and therersquos not just room but the need for more. Her hostility towards refugees is poisonous and her actions on immigration are harmful to our economy and society.But as well as restricting those we need to come here, itrsquos also affecting our rights to travel abroad. Irsquove had several constituents express concern at their ability to access homes in the EU. Itrsquos not just those fortunate to be in that position but also those with family abroad. Even in my own family, my nephew is married to a Pole and my youngest sonrsquos partner is German. Even those just holidaying briefly abroad will find costs increased and the security of reciprocal healthcare rights lost.Brexit consequences are now being felt and theyrsquore unormly grim, with no redeeming features. Hopefully, a No Deal situation can be avoided but the Prime Ministerrsquos posturing is dangerous, and any deal will be less favourable than what we had before. Critical weeks lie ahead in Parliament but itrsquos about damage limitation, not delivering for the countryrsquos best interests.Finally, as Christmas nears, I hope those that can will give to charity. The need is great and it can also be a great present. My family are used to receiving animal sponsorship and Irsquove extended it to other support, both environmental and humanitarian. Take a look and see whatrsquos there.

title: town-centre-planned-new-town-blindwells-redesigned-scrap-mini-retail-park-plans
story: The first residents of the new town of Blindwells are expected to move in by September next year.However, developers Hargreaves have revealed that the masterplan for the town, which will see an initial population in , new homes, has been revised to create a new shopping centre to fit demand.Speaking during a virtual public consultation on the detailed plans for the town centre, Iain Slater from Hargreaves, said that while they had initially been steeredby East Lothian Council planners towards a mini retail park and supermarket at he heart of the town, times had changed.He said: ldquoRetail has changed signicantly. While it was once all about going to the supermarket for a big shop, now it is more about deliveries and just going out to buy what you want for that evening.ldquoEast Lothian Council had guided us towards a mini retail park but it is not really sustainable, which is why we have gone back to the town centre.Mr Slater said that the developers had redrawn the town centre to create smaller shops with residential properties above them.Drawings produced during the webinar showed the new town centre based around a body of water to be named The Princes Loch at the north of the site.A market square and Mercat Cross appeared in artistrsquos impressions of the new high street, while boutique shops with four-storey-high buildings lined it, with ground floor shops and flats above.Proposed on the new high street are also a health centre, gym, family pub and restaurant, and cafes.And at the loch itself, there are plans for a potential cultural centre for the Battle of Prestonpans Trust, which has been in discussions with developers to mark the historic battle on the site.Developers also confirmed that initial hopes for a railway station in Blindwells had been ruled out by Network Rail, although it might be revisited when the town expands.East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Development Plan includes the initial delivery of Blindwells with a town centre, housing and new primary school.It also has a larger area of land to the east of the town ndash which sits between Prestonpans and Tranent ndashwhich has been dubbed Greater Blindwells for future expansion.Mr Slater said that as well as a possible rail station in Greater Blindwells, there was also the possibility of a new secondary school being built but added that this was still ldquoat a very early stage in plans for the future.Current education plans for children and young people moving into Blindwells will see primary-school children bussed to classes at neighbouring Cockenzie Primary School until completion of the new primary school, now due to be delivered on site for school session  .Secondary-school pupils will travel to Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans.Concerns about the travel plans for school pupils, impact of the new town on the existing junctions on and off the A, and environmental impact were all raised by members of the public during the virtual consultation.Asked about the demographic planned for the new town, James Fraser from EMA Architects, which produced the masterplan, said the aim was to build a community.He said: ldquoIt is about trying to create a community, so all types of people will be welcome, from first-timebuyers to families and older people looking to downsize to a smaller home.The consultation remains open online until January  for comments atwww.blindwellsconsultation

title: reopening-swimming-pool-musselburgh-sports-centre-delayed
story: It was due to have reopened on Sunday, but "an issue during commissioning" has caused a delay.The pool has been closed since October  to enable a new replacement moving floor to be installed.This provides deeper or shallower depths to allow for dferent activities, like ing or childrens swimming.A spokesperson for enjoyleisure, which manages the facility, said: "The pool was closed to enable a new replacement moving floor to be installed, which is a major investment in the long-term sustainability of the swimming pool for the benefit of the community and a wide range of users."However, the work has encountered an issue during commissioning and will delay the reopening."We are working with the contractors to ensure that this is rectied as soon as possible."Whilst we are extremely disappointed in having to take this decision, the care of our customers is always our top priority and, while we know many people will be disappointed by the delay in reopening, we hope they will understand that it is for safety reasons."We are in the process of contacting everyone who has a booking that will be affected by this delay and will announce a new reopening date as soon as we can."

title: presents-left-prestonpans-bus-shelter-every-day-advent
story: Throughout this month, the anonymous kind souls behind the @PPansBus Shelter Twitter account are dropping off a gt each day for people to find and keep.Not only that but Pencaitland-based artist Lynn Fraser has painted seasonal pictures on the shelter to cheer up passers-by.Lynn told the Courier: ldquoIrsquove been following @PPansBusShelter on Twitter for a couple of years now and they just do these lovely things they leave tiny little figures sitting on little seats in the bus stop. Itrsquos just really quirky and it makes me smile.ldquoFor National Poetry Day, they put up poems on posters all round the bus shelter.ldquoBut I donrsquot know who they are!ldquoWhoever secretly runs the Twitter account leaves a little gt every day for anyone to find.ldquoI messaged them and said Irsquod like to paint Christmas scenes on the shelter, and they said go for it! So I did.A spokesperson for the Twitter account of the Northfield House bus shelter on Preston Road told the Courier: ldquoEach year the bus shelter is decorated for Christmas and, last year, small mystery packages were left in the run-up to Christmas.ldquoThis year, in conjunction with other bus stops on Twitter , Prestonpans Bus Shelter is taking part in #BusStopAdvent and small gtsare being left daily in the bus shelter.ldquoPeople who find a gt are encouraged to share on Twitter using the hashtag #BusStopAdvent.Lynn added: ldquoI love that they put out this little smile for the community. I just wanted to add to the fun.

title: lifeboat-crew-don-antlers-reindeer-run
story: More than a dozen members of Dunbarrsquos voluntary RNLI crew will pull on their wellies, waterproofs and lejackets. . . but not for a rescue.Instead, they are going to be clocking up the steps for a lsquoReindeer Runrsquo to raise money for the RNLI.Becs Millar, part of the inshore leboat crew, is among those stepping up to the challenge, which takes place on Saturday.She said: ldquoThe reindeer run is something the RNLI traditionally do.ldquoI took part in one about nine years ago over in Stirling and it is just something they like to do to as part of the fundraising.ldquoThis year, with Covid, we are just looking to raise funds as much as possible.ldquoOur donations are down signicantly, like others in the third sector.ldquoWe are going to do it in Dunbar up at Winterfield Park. We are planning to head up there so we can have the Land Rover on hand in case anybody does get called out. We will be doing laps round the field there.ldquoThere are some fitter lsquoreindeersrsquo in the pack and they may go and venture through the town.Becs, who has been a member of the Dunbar RNLI crew for six years, will be joined by about  fellow crew members in full kit, with helmets swapped for reindeer antlers, for the fundraising event at noon.Together, the volunteers are aiming to run, jog or walk a combined  kilometres ndash the equivalent distance of Dunbar Harbour to East Linton ndash while wearing full personal protective equipment .Coronavirus has had a major impact on groups across the country looking to fundraise, with events being called off due to social distancing restrictions.Dunbarrsquos RNLI has found it no dferent than many others, with a number of events being postponed.Becs, who recently started up her own personal trainer business, said: ldquoWersquove got a great fundraising team and traditionally we would have the leboat fete, which we do every year and is a massive fundraiser for the RNLI.ldquoThings like Strictly for the Leboats, which Veronica Davies [Dunbar RNLI fundraising committee chairwoman] is still looking to do at some point as well.ldquoTherersquos Dunbar Civic Week, when we would tend to be out on High Street, and the leboat fete, which is the main one.ldquoWe have not been able to go out and do talks in schools or with adult groups and most are very generous with donations to us.ldquoThe town are massive supporters, with us obviously being so close to the sea.ldquoWe are so lucky to have such great support in the community.To make a donation, go to reindeerrun.rnli.org fundraising dunbars-crew-follow-the-herd

title: coronavirus-scotlands-self-isolation-period-dropped-14-10-days
story: The Scottish Government has announced that the self-isolation period forinternationaltravellers and positive contacts will be reduced from the current  days to  days.Currently, anyone inScotlandwho tests positive for Covid- should self-isolate for  days but close contacts should quarantine for  days.The move comes after the four UK chief medical officersagreed the latest evidence allows them to be confident that self-isolation of just  days will be sufficient to suppress the spread of the virus.When does the new rule come into force The new rulewill come into action from Monday.It means that anyone who has been contacted through Test and Protect, including through thecoronavirusapp, or their health board, and told to self-isolate, should do so for  days, instead of .Who  does the rules apply to A close contact - whichincludes members of the same household who test positive for the virus ndash who will now only need to self-isolate for  days.Anyone who is required to self-isolate after arriving from Scotland from certain overseas countries will also be able to stop self-isolating after  days.Anyone who is a ing traveller or who has been identied as a contact of a case and is on day ,, or  of an existing -day isolation period on Monday can end their isolation on Monday .What has the Scottish Government said HealthSecretary Jeane Freeman said: ldquoSelf-isolation, both for contacts identied by Test and Protect and through the foreign travel quarantine requirements, is critical to protecting people and reducing the spread of Covid-.ldquoFollowing their review of the latest evidence and having considered the joint recommendation of UK CMOs from all four nations, we have agreed to reduce the required isolation period from  to  days.ldquoWhile self-isolation may be for a shorter period, it remains vital that everyone who is required to do so remains at their home or other named address for this time. Only by doing this can we break the chain of transmission of the virus, protect the NHS and save lives.Does it apply to the rest of the UK The change to  days will also apply in England and Northern Ireland from Monday and it already applies in Wales.In a joint statement, the four UK CMOs said: ldquoSelf-isolation is essential to reducing the spread of Covid as it breaks the chains of transmission.ldquoAfter reviewing the evidence, we are now confident that we can reduce the number of days that contacts self-isolate from  days to  days. People whofrom countries which are not on thetravelcorridor list should also self-isolate for  days instead of  days.ldquoPeople who test positive should continue to self-isolate for  days from onset of symptoms or  days from point of taking a positive testasymptomatic. We urge everyone to self-isolate when appropriate, it will save lives.

title: covid-vaccine-poll-reveals-famous-scots-people-think-promote-take-up
story: NHS England is reportedly drawing up a plan to enlist ldquosensible celebrities and influencers to help boost take-up amid fears of vaccine scepticismDuring the s the King of Rock and Roll Elvis Presley was famously photographed getting his polio vaccination before appearing on the Ed Sullivan Show ndash the resulting campaign was successful in getting more young people to receive the jag.Experts have theorised that a similar idea could be used now Covid- vaccines are being approved by medical regulators in record time.A poll, carried out by Dfley Partnership and ScotPulse, asked  Scots: ldquoWhich,any, of the well known Scots listed below do you think could be used to encourage as many people as possible to take [the vaccine] Alex Ferguson, Janey Godley, Ewan McGregor, Chris Hoy, Elaine C Smith, Susan Calman, James McAvoy, Brian Cox , Gerald Butler, James Cosmo, Judy Murray, Richard Madden, Edith Bowman and Kelly Macdonald also received votes.The poll asked more generally about coronavirus vaccination too, finding the vast majority of Scots will take it when they are offered it. More than three-quarters said they would definitely receive it while just % said they wonrsquot.Mark Dfley wrote: ldquoA more detailed look at the data highlights few signicant dferences in attitudes among population sub-groups.ldquoIn terms of opposition to taking the vaccine, women are slightly more likely than men to be opposed , while those at either end of the age scale are more supportive of taking the vaccine than those in the middle age groups so, just % of those aged under  and % of those aged + say they probably or definitely wonrsquot take the vaccine, while this rises to as high as % among those aged -. title: scottish-panoramas-castle-campbell-romance-stone-setting
story: Castle Campbell, sitting high in Dollar Glen, is neither the showiest nor the most storied, but it offers enough of both to make the journey there worthwhile.Indeed, the journey to it is at least half the fun. The steep walk up to the castle from Dollarwill either take you up through woodsyou keep left, or,you go right, will squeeze you between rocks and waterfalls, an imposing prospect that can leave you feeling like yoursquove just stepped into an episode of Game of Thrones. There are no dragons on hand, but you might spot green woodpeckers, dippers or nuthatchesyou are lucky.The castle itself sits on a rocky outcrop carved by the Burns of Care and Sorrow . It dates from the early s, when it was known as Castle Glume. Ownership passed to Colin Campbell, st Earl of Argyll, through marriage, and he chose to change the name to Castle Campbell via an Act of Parliament in .John Knox and Mary Queen of Scots were both said to have visited the castle in the th century. Knox reputedly gave a sermon while he was there. A century later, it was occupied by Oliver Cromwellrsquos forces during the Civil War. But after the execution of the eighth Earl of Argyll in  for his initial support of the parliamentarians , the castle began to fall into disrepair.By the Victorian era, it was a picturesque ruin attracting the attention of passing artists including Horatio McCulloch who painted the castle twice, in  and again in . In , the great Victorian artist Joseph Mallord William Turner made two sketches of the castle that were to become part of the Turner Bequest to the nation in . Sir Walter Scott also visited a couple of times in the s, but, for once, he had nothing much to say about it in his writings.It wasnrsquot until  that the castle passed into the control of the National Trust for Scotland and it is now administered by Historic Environment Scotland. What remains is an imposing tower house some  metres high , a courtyard and gardens amidst a setting that has the Ochils as a backdrop and the Forth Valley spread out below.Because of the coronavirus pandemic, the castle is currently closed to visitors, but it remains a marker in the landscape, a marker of Scottish history and our ability to find romance in stone and setting. title: doug-marr-britain-thrall-snake-oil-salesmen-sensational-slogans
story: The crisis habit hasnrsquot come on suddenly, but built up over time. The tabloids have been around for many years, but became the main suppliers of the sensational from the mid-s. The timing coincided with shortening attention spans amongst readers and growing unwillingness to work at longer and more nuanced writing.Tabloid headlines, short sentences and even shorter words take the hard work out of thinking. Headlines that puffed, ldquoGotcha! and ldquoIt Was The Sun Wot Won It pandered to our laziness. Since then, all-pervasive social media has further undermined critical thinking and calm judgment.Clickbait relies on our thirst for sensation and the bizarre. Social media provides a  for sensationalists, conspiracy cranks and the downright deranged. Rapidly clicking a mouse requires neither concentration nor reflection.Things dont necessarily have to be y to be true or profound. Abraham Lincoln used the  words of his Gettysburg Address to place the American Civil War in its context. Now,  years and  presidents later, Donald Trump trivialised politics by sending thousands of semi-literate tweets. Laughable but effective, as he instinctively identied and plugged into the modern addiction for the short and superficial. Itrsquos not hard to understand Make America Great Again or even Get Brexit Done. Other populist leaders have followed his lead, creating what Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Anne Applebaum, describes as ldquocascades of hood that represent a threat to democracy.The threat extends beyond the political sphere. Fringe elements, including conspiracy theorists such as QAnon, opponents of G networks and anti-vaxxers, exploit our vulnerability and receptiveness to the soundbite, slogan and sensational. The young are most at risk and education has a vital role to help them understand and deal with the threat.Unfortunately, the all-important skills of critical thinking and how to question sources, best developed through history, geography and modern studies, are at risk of marginalisation in an increasingly overcrowded curriculum. Many youngsters will study none of those subjects beyond early secondary. In the age of the sloganeer, the sensationalist and the snake oil salesman, those skills have never been more important.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: fidelma-cook-going-home-home-las-molieres
story: As usual it is worse at night when silence rules the corridors and the large French windows with their shroud of black shutters give no light back.In my bed neither book nor computer block my thoughts and my mind once again goes racing into areas Irsquod rather not. Scenes ndash bad scenes ndash are conjured up and along with them possible outcomes that set my heart racing and my breathing grow shallow and fast.For all has changed here yet again. I am no longer crossing the road to the other unit, thank God. I would have gone downhill fast in there I know.No, Irsquom going home. Home to Las Molieres. Home alone with this time no Ceacutesar, no companionby my side to mind and keep me company as the hours tick by.It seems now that with my walking much improved and, bizarrely, my general health too, they feel I can do it. They have more faith in me I think than I have.Having been here since March it feels asI am about to step off a precipice, hands tied behind my back, and no-one there any longer to catch me.I will not always be alone. A nurse will check me morning and late evening. An aide will possibly,I wish, come in three or four times a week to see what help I might need around the house. A physio will come daily and with her help I hope to master walking outside again and strive for balance control.A prescription will be given for wheelchair and Zimmer although I hope to use them as little as possible andmyself to an upright human position.And I have the devoted Miriam for whom I give daily thanks. She will come morning and night to unshutter and shutter the house ndash the first check of the day.She will also get any shopping, prescriptions I need, and will do the housework. Finally, we have come to a financial arrangement for that which makes me feel immeasurably better but in no way recompenses for million kindnesses she shows me and has shown me over the years.Deb and Alistair too are ready to come whether called or not and also do shopping. They will dose me with English and a shared black humour sadly absent in Miriam.For the obvious and many reasons le at LM cannot be as it was before. I must move often not sit peering into the world from my Mac with a vin close to hand.And, despite the circumstances, I must come to terms with the loneliness of my isolation which was eating me far more than I realised before all this happened.I must strive to cook properly to keep up my strength for the treatments still to come and not rely on vin rouge and crisps as a substitute for dinner. I already know my first meal though ndash yes, my beloved oven chips with two eggs cracked in for the final minutes.I must hope the treatment side effects are deal-able with when alone and frightened butnot the SSR where I am have promised they will bring me back to deal with them.But of all I must learn, the most important is to try to live without Ceacutesar, my mad beautul boy nuzzling at my feet or disdainfully refusing my entreaties to come in for the night and stop howling at the moon.Learn to live without his long hound nose nudging my arm and elbow for attention his deep sleep breathing on the tiles by my side his Afghan perfume as he dances around me.Today on her visit, tears streaming I asked Miriamshe would remove his feeding bowls and bed to the attic before I entered the house a week from tomorrow.Already thought of and done. As an aside she says,I want, she will stay all night on the first night. I want.I will still see them of course, and him, but Irsquoll not feel him as I often did Portia, for he lives on apparently happy where. And no, I wonrsquot ask for him to be brought to me to visit for I couldnrsquot take seeing him being driven away.The real fear will come with nightfall for I have always been frightened of the dark and the countryside outside LM has a cloying blackness peculiar to La France Profonde.It presses on the face, suffocating, invasive, alien, and the clarity of the stars does not make up for that unless in the presence of another awe-struck human.And I hope that Las Molieres herself will be kinder to me ndash remember the love I lavished on her in those early years before I felt her turn.Fancul I know but houses have souls and somewhere along the line I upset hers.Well, Irsquoll find out soon enough. There will be one more column from here and I should already be home when you read it.Wish me luck. Onwards and upwardhelliponce more.

title: hurrah-home-delivered-home-made-italian-food-ron-mackennas-review
story: GlasgowONCE upon a time on any newspaper I was ever a news guy on, what Irsquom about to do would have sparked a strike. Instantly. A reporter touched a camera. A reporter took a photograph. Aargh.I actually never ever saw it happen. In decades. Not once. Tonight, thanks to unintended consequences of Tier Four bubble-mania, it sparks nothing more than a frisson of all-round irritation.Okay, mostly from me. The fat food critic who doesnrsquot even own a camera. Never has. Canrsquot even work the things.Anyway, the doorbell has gone, the delivery been accepted and laid on the kitchen table. Tinfoil is unfolded, space is cleared, stuff unboxed, iPhone unleashed and the new ritual gone through. Snap, snap, snap. While the family stand by, arms folded, and wearily watch.Hang on, thatrsquos no good. Try there, move that fork, bloody placemats, who left this here, is there a light in our house that doesnrsquot cast a shadow  Yadada. While hunger builds.By the time Irsquove finished, well, itrsquos kinda killed the moment. And the food still has to be heated. Sigh.I can tell you now Marta the Italian lady, off Facebook of all things, who freshly made this tray of lasagne and also that tray of spinach and ricotta cannelloni, and has written these before-eating instructions, has a better oven than ours.Twenty minutes at   Never.These trays are big. More like  at , is the conclusion after numerous oven door openings, finger proddings, fork stabbings.Why Facebook  Frankly  When it comes to better food the internet is broken, a junkyard of broken promises, wishful thinking, stalled websites andyoursquore lucky to find an updated Google Local or link page it usually leads eventually to extremely long order-in-advance times, with an annoying gold-rush log-back-on when menus are released.Though I have got to say itrsquos the Scottish and UK governments which have unnecessarily broken the better restaurants.Anyway, only on Facebook, the clunkiest of all food mediums, do I find someone who will allow me to bag some fresh non-freezer van food and have it delivered while Irsquom still capable of remembering what I once fancied.Moan over. Food ready. We sit, we get the big spoon out. Early doors  This is a proper lasagne. Bubbled on top, browned righteously, parting into portions that reveal the tell-tale softness of fresh pasta and most importantly, most reassuringly, there is layer after layer of it.To me, a lasagne in Italy, one made by someone-you-know in someone-you-knowrsquos actual house always has loads of layers, the thinnest spreading of ingredient separating them, and a creamy bechamel in there just thick enough to temper everything. Like this.Layers so fine it looks like alternating stripes. This is a good lasagne, we agree, and vote we would order it again. Though maybe a bit bolder with the seasoning next time, please Onto that cannelloni. Fat long tubes, draped in cheeses stuffed with enough spinach to give the ricotta a peppery kick, once again the pasta buttery smooth, those fat tubes holding everything in place until it sprawls at the touch of fork.Wersquoll still be finishing both of these off tomorrow night. And enjoying them.Oh, there are a couple of caprese salads, ordered out of curiosity, served on cocktail sticks, doused in olive oil, the basil surprisingly lively. A bag of handmade, heart-shaped, cinnamon flavoured biscuit things from abruzzo.Now, Irsquove got to tell you I actually emailed three dferent small-scale finer food suppliers on Facebook. Only Marta replied on the same day, one of the others not even the same week. We live in dficult times.But it is another of the unintended consequences of these times that wersquore able to virtually go right into other peoplersquos homes and have their freshly made and pretty good food brought straight to our own homes.And that, at least, canrsquot be a bad thing.Martarsquos Genuine Italian FoodOrdered from FacebookMenu: Simple choices of either lasagne or cannelloni, orb, a caprese salad or two, and some freshly made biscuits. Price: A tray of lasagne or spinach and ricotta cannelloni, that would easily feed four, came in at pound each with an extra fiver for delivery.  Service: Hey, it was delivered with a smile.  Atmosphere: Umm, wersquore eating at home so apart from the carry on taking photos all was sweetness and light.  Food: Handmade and homemade lasagne made by an Italian person and brought to your home to be heated up in the oven. Whatrsquos not to like

title: uzma-mir-advent-calendars-christmas-movies-carol-singing-turkey-trimmings---cant-wait
story: Four shops later, and my plans to go for a chic navy and gold theme were replaced by a desperate any-colour-thatrsquos-left scheme. But, as I sat back on Wednesday night, hot chocolate in hand, fire roaring, staring at my six-foot tree with gaudy fluorescent pink baubles, silver peacocks, chocolate Santas and twinkly, flashing coloured lights, I felt a flash of joy not experienced for many months.It took me back to an argument I had at eight years old with my mum and dad who didnrsquot celebrate Christmas, because in their minds it was a religious festival that they, as Muslims, could not celebrate.My dad told me how he had attended a Christian college in Lahore under the British Raj and had memories of being forced to sing hymns every morning at assembly.Me: Ok, but I just want a tree. Them: No, because we are not Christians. Me: With lights, tinsel and baubles, please, oh and an angel. Them: Christmas is for Christians. Me:Everybody has a tree.Do you really want me to be dferent  Them: OK wersquoll get a treehellipBut no carols and definitely no Midnight Mass.Unfortunately for them, I loved singing so would sneak out for choir practice, belting out O Come All Ye Faithful and Away in a Manger with all associated harmonies, just for the sheer, unadulterated joy of it.But somewhere between then and my th birthday I began to feel that Christmas didnrsquot quite sit right with me. It felt strangely unfulfilling and I couldnrsquot understand why. I could join in with the playground chat about whether I was hoping for a Chopper or a Sindy for Christmas, and Irsquod sing the solo in the church, but something was missing.I recognise now that what I was feeling was the half-pleasure that comes from a type of cultural appropriation. I was appropriating Christmas for myself, without fully understanding what I was celebrating, and that felt more than a little hollow. That year there was no request for a tree from me and ours was the only front room on the street without a tree, although my sister, who was nine, in a quiet act of rebellion against the rest of us, set one up in her bedroom.Thereafter, Christmas was always a welcome and peaceful break from school, university and then work, and a happy time spent with my atheist in-laws, which, whilst I enjoyed, I never fully understood what we were celebrating. It was really the worst sort of cognitive dissonance but one which I trained myself to accept to lsquofit inrsquo.Itrsquos taken no less than a pandemic to persuade me otherwise. Now, like a crazed pleasure addict I seek more of the warm glow that comes with gazing lovingly at my tree, receiving online deliveries at the rate of four per day, and watching my bank balance fluctuate between quite healthy to overdraft at an alarming rate.The buying, the wrapping, the cards, the food, the table decorations, the sparkly clothes ndash I have decided to do it all to get a fix of much-needed cheer at the end of the weirdest year ever. I did argue a few weeks ago in this column that we should all go for a simple, scaled back Christmas this year, but no, this six-foot tree has persuaded me that we all need a bit of pleasure in these tricky times and we shouldnrsquot be too fussy about where we find that. My own kids having been raised as full-blown mixed race, mixed heritage, best of both types, have definitely got the hang of this whole damn festivals thing ndash hold on to every possible opportunity to extract cash gts from your loved ones, go with the flow, sod the culture wars and enjoy.So this year Irsquom going to fully culturally appropriate Christmas and milk it for all it is worth: From themed advent calendars and a dferent Christmas movie every day to socially distanced carols in my street and turkey with all the trimmings, Irsquom here for Christmas for the first time ever.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: issue-day-obama-sparks-ufo-intrigue
story: How so During an interview on US TV programme, the Late Show with Stephen Colbert, Barack Obama told the host that during his time in the Oval Office, he had sought classied information on extraterrestrials. But, intriguingly, he refused to ulge what he had been told in response.What did he say Reflecting on his presidency, he commented that there were times when ldquoprying information out of the bowels of an agency can be challenging, to which Colbert said: ldquoUFOs  Did you ask about that  Obama said he ldquocertainly asked about it and when pressed further to explain what he had been told, he said in a serious tone: ldquoI canrsquot tell you. Sorry.The host took that as a confirmation of their existence Colbert said he would ldquotake that as a yes becausethere were none, yoursquod say there was none and Obama then signed off by saying: ldquoFeel free to think that.Hersquos not the first president to spark intrigue on the subject During an interview with his son Don Trump Jr in the summer, President Trump said he knew some interesting things about Roswell - referring to rumors and speculation around a  United States Army Air Forces balloon crash at a ranch near Roswell, New Mexico, said to involve a UFO. Trump Jr askedhis father would ever ulge information about the incident to ldquolet us know whatrsquos really going on and Trump responded: ldquoI wonrsquot talk to you about what I know about it, but itrsquos very interesting.Jimmy Carter During the  presidential campaign, democratic challenger Carter was open about his belief that he had seen a UFO in  one evening in Georgia. He said that along with a group of about  others, he spotted ldquothe darndest thing Irsquove ever seen in the sky, describing the object as ldquovery bright [with] changing colours and about the size of the moon that ldquohovered about  degrees above the horizon and moved in toward the earth and away before disappearing into the distance. He pledged to never ridicule anyone who claimed to have seen a UFO and that he would encourage openness about the subjecthe was elected.However After entering the White House, he softened on this vow, saying that to release some information could have ldquodefence implications and potentially pose a threat to national security.It comes ashelliphellipRetired Israeli general, Professor Haim Eshed,  - who ran Israelrsquos national space programme for  years - made some startling declarations, including a claim that humanity has already made contact with aliens, but the majority of humanity had been kept unaware of this as the world was not deemed to be ready to handle the news. Eshed also claimed President Trump had been on the verge of disclosing the existence of aliens but that a "Galactic Federation" had pressured him not to do so till humans are ready.

title: royal-society-edinburgh-acclaims-janey-godleys-medicine-helping-stop-covid-19-spread
story: The Royal Society of Edinburgh, Scotlands national academy of science and letters says that Janey Godleys voiceover skits complete with comedic catchphrase Frank, get the door has been "most effective" in getting the public to take action to prevent the spread of the virus.The alternative voice of Nicola Sturgeon has been praised for her laughter medicine which isgetting people to engage over repetitive prevention messages of social distancing, staying at home, washing hands and wearing a mask.There have been , confirmed cases of Covid- in Scotland and , people have died following a positive test for the virus, according to the latest Scottish government figures.While Ms Godleys videos have brought light relief to many, the RSE said they have also served "a much more important purpose of reinforcing the key messages of stay at home delivered to the public by the First Minister".Dr Rebekah Widdowfield, chief executive of the RSE said: ldquoThe importance of clear communication around a public issue like coronavirus cannot be overstated. While the Governmentrsquos daily briefing has been a steady, reliable way to provide updates to the public, the repetitive nature of the guidance can cause the impact to be somewhat dampened."This is where Janey Godleyrsquos contribution has been its most effective ndash by adding comedy and relatability to the content, it has encouraged the public to re-engage with the messaging."He spoke as Ms Godley herself has spoken about the positive impact of her viral social media videos in which she provides a voice-over to the First Ministerrsquos daily coronavirus briefings, in an interview for the RSE.:Trolled Scots comedian Janey Godley hits back at claims she brings it on herselfShe said: ldquoI basically imagined a wee woman called Jeanette at the bus stop, and how she would translate the daily briefings to her friend, wee Agnes.She said the Covid briefings were so "same, same, same, same, same and monotonous, so I kind of tried to make the message stronger".She said she did the improvised voiceovers on her phone because she was "bored in the house"."When the Covid briefings came out, theresa lot of blah blah blah here, let me pick this up a pace."The point was the message was getting out."The Frank, who features in her catchphrase, was originally a customer in a pub she owned between  and  in the east end of Glasgow."Whenever there was any problems Id go, Frank, get the door, and hed hold the door, while he read a paperback cowboy novel. He was so laid back," she said in an interview for the RSE. "I am sure he has passed away now, but he doesnt know he is dead famous."She also highlighted that the comedy sketches are ldquonot about the politician, and itrsquos not about the politics, itrsquos about getting the message about coronavirus out there, in an informed, relatable and mildly offensive way.The interview, which will be premiered on the RSErsquos Facebook page and YouTube channel at  pm on Friday , was organised as part of the RSErsquos Post-Covid- Futures Commissionrsquos Public Debate and Participation workstream, and is the first of two events with Ms Godley around the topic of communication during the pandemic.Ms Godley will also feature in a Voices of Covid Who Cuts Through  Why  event also featuring Professor Jason Leitch and Mona Siddiqui and hosted by RSE president, Professor Dame Anne Glover, to be held on Thursday December  at .pm.

title: self-isolation-period-covid-contacts-reduced-10-days
story: The Scottish Government has announced that the self-isolation period for international travellers and positive contacts will be reduced from the current  days to  days.Currently, anyone in Scotland who tests positive for Covid- should self-isolate for  days but close contacts should quarantine for  days.The move comes after the four UK chief medical officersagreed the latest evidence allows them to be confident that self-isolation of just  days will be sufficient to suppress the spread of the virus.The new rule, which will come into action from Monday, means that anyone who has been contacted through Test and Protect, including through the coronavirus app, or their health board, and told to self-isolate, should do so for  days.:Coronavirus: Fears Edinburgh could be stuck in tier A close contact includes members of the same household who test positive for the virus ndash who will now only need to self-isolate for  days.Anyone who is required to self-isolate after arriving from Scotland from certain overseas countries will also be able to stop self-isolating after  days.Anyone who is a ing traveller or who has been identied as a contact of a case and is on day ,, or  of an existing -day isolation period on Monday can end their isolation on Monday .Health Secretary Jeane Freeman said: ldquoSelf-isolation, both for contacts identied by Test and Protect and through the foreign travel quarantine requirements, is critical to protecting people and reducing the spread of Covid-.ldquoFollowing their review of the latest evidence and having considered the joint recommendation of UK CMOs from all four nations, we have agreed to reduce the required isolation period from  to  days.:Coronavirus: Glasgow schools face industrial action threat over remote learningldquoWhile self-isolation may be for a shorter period, it remains vital that everyone who is required to do so remains at their home or other named address for this time. Only by doing this can we break the chain of transmission of the virus, protect the NHS and save lives.The change to  days will also apply in England and Northern Ireland from Monday and it already applies in Wales.In a joint statement, the four UK CMOs said: ldquoSelf-isolation is essential to reducing the spread of Covid as it breaks the chains of transmission.ldquoAfter reviewing the evidence, we are now confident that we can reduce the number of days that contacts self-isolate from  days to  days. People whofrom countries which are not on the travel corridor list should also self-isolate for  days instead of  days.ldquoPeople who test positive should continue to self-isolate for  days from onset of symptoms or  days from point of taking a positive testasymptomatic. We urge everyone to self-isolate when appropriate, it will save lives.

title: scottish-independence-unstoppable-says-plaid-cymru-leader-welsh-indyref-pledge
story: Mr Price said support for an independent Wales was now at its ldquohighest in history while devolution was under attack from Boris Johnsonrsquos Westminster Government.The party leader also said the need to hold a referendum had been ldquoaccelerated due to his belief that Scotland will become an independent nation by  and that Brexit had made a united Ireland possible.Mr Price has said thathe is able to command a majority of MSs in the Senedd after next May, the country will be offered one binary choice referendum on Welsh independence by , within the first term of a Plaid government.:Sturgeon worried Johnson lsquoplanning for no-dealrsquo Brexit as key question on independence raisedUnveiling his plans at a press conference earlier today, Mr Price said: ldquoDevolution itself ndash that most basic democratic principle that decisions affecting Wales should be made in Wales ndash is under attack from Boris Johnsonrsquos Conservatives.ldquoMeanwhile, the demand for another independence referendum in Scotland is becoming unstoppable and by  Scotland could well be an independent country. And Brexit has also given further impetus to the calls for a united Ireland.ldquoWales is in real danger of being left behind as part of a rump United Kingdom, in a new England-and-Wales formation ndash which would be the ultimate worst of all worlds.ldquoIt is for these reasons that I therefore pledge today that subject to party approval, a Plaid Cymru government, able to command a majority in the Senedd, will offer a referendum on independence for Wales in its first term."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price","description": "Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media WYXOmic poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests WYXOmic.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": In June, a poll revealed  per cent of voters in Wales supported independencethere was a referendum the next day, the highest ever level of support recorded.But the same poll also found  per cent of people asked would choose to abolish the Welsh Parliamentthey were given a referendum on doing so.At the SNPrsquos th Annual National Conference last month, Mr Price promised that his ldquofirst official phone call as the first pro-independence First Minister of Wales next May to you First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, as he pledged to bring two nations together in a Celtic Summit.Mr Price said he is keen to ldquocement and enhance the relationship between the two nations, and, as First Minister of Wales, has promised a ldquoCeltic Summit in summer  where common aims and purpose can be mapped out ldquoas independence and mutual co-operation becomes the new normal.

title: herald-diary-carry-on-life-can
story: Nowadays the Carry On flicks are much maligned for their seaside postcard vision of the UK. Though surely this was a more accurate interpretation of le on these shores than anything filmed by Ken Russell or David Lean After all, therersquos only one way to describe Britainrsquos current ballyhoo with Brussels: Carry On Brexit. The Diary admits that it, too, is often a Carry On caper in newspaper form, as the following stories from our archives underline.For instance, we once discovered that the organiser of a conference in Newfoundland on the subject of Training for Survival and Rescue at Sea was a Captain Drown.Carry On CodingA COMPUTER-SAVVY reader once told us: ldquoOf course my passwordrsquos insecure. So would you beyou were replaced every six months.Carry On DrivingA GLASGOW reader told us about his optimistic pal who was stopped by the police for speeding. The officer came over to his car and asked: ldquoDo you know why you were stopped  His friend came out with the hopeful, yet misguided, reply: ldquoAre you possibly looking for directions Carry On KiddingA TEACHER desperate for the Christmas break swore to us that he asked his class what the dference was between ignorance and apathy. A pupil replied: ldquoDonrsquot know and donrsquot care.Carry On CrashingA READER Recalled that when Stornoway got its first set of traffic lights in the s, an elderly chap from rural Lewis drove in for his annual shopping and went straight through the red light, narrowly missing an old dear on her zimmer.When the cops stopped him and askedhe saw the lights, he innocently replied: ldquoOh, aye. Theyrsquore ferry nice.Carry On ClubbingVISITING the golf club, a reader heard a senior chap playing nearby announce he had consumed his five-a-day before leaving the house. A fellow golfer askedhe was on a health kick. The chap replied: ldquoPills: statin, warfarin, prostate, beta-blockers and now hay fever.Carry On HoundingMISSING the point was the chap in the park who didnrsquot clean up after his dog. When an irate fellow park user pointed out the sign stating "Dog fouling, maximum fine pound", he replied: ldquoNothing for me to worry about. My dog doesnrsquot play football.Carry On CareeringREADERS are always phoning in with daft comments. One chap told us: ldquoIrsquom looking to start my own business, recycling discarded chewing gum. I just need help getting it off the ground.

title: kevin-mckenna-earth-scotland-want-part-eu-anyway
story: At the same time another bacchanal ndash just as unedying ndash will be in spate, fuelled by the piety of the self-righteous. They will lecture us on the dark forces that impelled Brexit and portray those who supported it as semi-literate yokels who, in their ignorance, were incapable of comprehending the issues. On my travels throughout Englandrsquos northern regions following the  referendum, it became clear that this was a smear every bit as contrived as the fiction of taking back control.Rather, many of them had felt the chill of the European Unionrsquos neo-liberal, free market instincts in their own communities. The EU, at its heart, is a corporate Xanadu where the writ of capitalism is given licence to roam. Wersquove known this for many years.In a  paper published by New Yorkrsquos Cornell University the academics Nathan Lillie and Ian Greer shone a torch on the iniquities at the heart of the EUrsquos industrial plan. ldquoConstruction employers, with the aid of the Commission of the EU, and acquiescence of national governments, have made it an integral part of their strategy to access opportunities outside the national state framework. In each of our country cases, construction employers are using migrant labour to push the industry toward a lsquolow-roadrsquo model of weaker collective bargaining and worker representation.This, they argued, enabled employers ldquoto protect themselves from legal liability, while isolating migrants from the economic and social norms of the host society. Put more plainly, the EU creates feeding grounds for capitalists to squeeze local workers and exploit foreign labour.Remainers who posed as liberal and progressive also chose to overlook the EUrsquos bullying of Greece as it sought to make it a vassal state. In this they were spurred on by German banks who have made more than euro billion in interest payments on Greek bonds since . Membership of the EU confers advantages but most of them accrue to those who already possess a disproportionate share of the worldrsquos bounty.The Nobel-prizewinning economist Paul Krugman also dismantled the moonbeams and unicorn narrative. ldquoI fairly often encounter assertions to the effect that Greece didnrsquot carry through on its promises that it failed to deliver the promised spending cuts, he wrote. ldquoNothing could be further from the truth. In reality, Greece imposed savage cuts in public services, wages of government workers and social benefits. He added: ldquoEuropean discourse is still dominated by ideas the continentrsquos elite would like to be true, but arenrsquot. And Europe is paying a terrible price for this monstrous self-indulgence.In effect, a capitalist troika ndash the IMF, European Central Bank and European Commission ndash was making ordinary Greeks pay not only for the greed of their own business elites but also for the irresponsible lending of German banks looking to make a quick buck.Working-class communities in Fe and the Western Isles have recently had a taste of what lies aheadan independent Scotland opts to climb on board the EU capitalist express. The Scottish Government was able to retreat behind the old state aid contrivance as it abandoned workers at the BiFab fabrication yards to the whims of global corporatism.Having made future membership a cornerstone of its independence offering, the SNP is thus keen to appear a supine acolyte of the EU, despite it being highly unlikely that Scotland will become a member any time soon. Its dealings with the Bab workers were both dishonest and craven. Across the rest of Europe there has always been room for manoeuvre and negotiation within the EUrsquos state aid regulations. The SNP though, ever eager to assist the global, neo-liberal procession, chose to disavow Scottish workers.The SNP knows that its stated future direction of economic travel will require an abrupt detouritrsquos serious about EU membership in the short-term. Thus it chooses not to highlight the obstacles. Not the least of these is the "sterlingisation" currency proposal contained in its Growth Commission report, a document now proving so brittle it may soon require to be housed in an air-tight chamber. A singular requirement of supplicant EU members is that their ldquoeconomic and monetary policy contains specic rules requiring the independence of central banks.The SNP has also hitched our future economy to the EUrsquos Growth and Stability Pact, a concordat which one prominent trade unionist described to me as ldquopeak neo-liberalism representing a massive danger to democracy. This is because it caps government deficits at three per cent of GDP and debt at % of GDP. Yet, as in its state-aid regulations, there is no absolute requirement to implement this.By following this an independent Scotland faced with trade deficits and lacking spending autonomy under sterlingisation leaves its citizens vulnerable to the predations of the credit jackals. A grown-up conversation needs to take place about thesethe SNP is genuinely serious about throwing Scotland into the arms of the EU. But the only pro-independence bodies advocating such are scorned by party lickspittles as ldquothose Common Weal types.Six years after the last independence referendum the SNP is no further forward in saying how it will secure a second one. Does anyone really believe that an In Out EU referendum will happen soon after independence is gained Authentic self-determination offers a one-time-only opportunity to develop a dferent type of economy. In the dismal argot of the Holyrood managerial class we can dare to alter the paradigm and change the conversation: to have an option for the poor and to unlock the full economic potential of working class communities.Independence gives Scotland a chance for popular democratic control over the economy and the state, but notthe EU has anything to do with it.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The HeraldRead more: Appeal for second-hand clothes for poor children should shame Scotland

title: coronavirus-scotland-christmas-shoppers-told-not-flout-travel-ban
story: Nicola Sturgeon issued the warning as Scotland recorded its highest daily number of new Covid- cases for two weeks ndash with , positive tests confirmed in the last -hour period ndash the highest daily total since November .Non-essential shops in  council areas, including Glasgow, Stirling and West Lothian have been allowed to re-open from am today with furster rules eased at pm ndash but as the areas remain in tier  of the Scottish Governmentrsquos coronavirus framework, people are banned from travelling to and from level  areas.The First Minister warned against people rushing out to the shops and reiterated that people will be breaking the lawthey travel from West Lothian to Edinburgh or from Lanarkshire to Glasgow for Christmas shopping.:Coronavirus: Fears Edinburgh could be stuck in tier She said: ldquoI cannot emphasise enough to you today that the very, very last thing we want to see is overcrowding in or around shops and shopping centres.The First Minister urged people to wait ldquoa day or two before shopping or to order online.Ms Sturgeon added: ldquoFor example, you should not travel to Edinburgh or Glasgow from outside these local authority areas, even for Christmas shopping.Police Scotlandrsquos chief constable, Iain Livingstone, reiterated that officers will not be setting up road blocks on local authority boundaries.He said: ldquoApart from legitimate exemptions, we should not be travelling in or out of level  areas.ldquoI have consistently said that I do not consider it appropriate or proportionate for police officers to set up road blocks or routinely stop vehicles simply to enforce travel restrictions.ldquoHowever, where breaches do come to our attention, officers will continue to respond with good sense, exercise discretion and of course, take enforcement action when required.ldquoI can assure you there will be dedicated, visible and pro-active patrols and operations across all our roads, theand breadth of Scotland to ensure vehicles and drivers are in a fit condition to drive.Mr Livingstone added: ldquoWe have issued, I think, almost  fixed penalty notices in regard to breaches of travel restrictions.:Coronavirus: Glasgow and  areas to move out of lockdownldquoThat underlines that when enforcement action is required, Police Scotland will take that enforcement action ndash but our starting point is always to encourage people to do the right thing.The First Minister warned that ldquoprogress against this virus can go into reverse very quicklywe donrsquot continue to take care and she warned shoppers to be careful.She added: ldquoIf you do go to the shops and you find the one you want to go to is crowded, perhaps come away and go to another one and come back later.ldquoAnd all of us ndash wherever we live ndash should be trying to shop locally. By doing that, we can also help to support businesses and jobs in our local area.ldquoIf you do go shopping, please go on your own ndash or in as small a group as possible. Or order online,you can, that way you can still get your shopping done, you can still support the retail sector, but you are avoiding spaces that might be busy or crowded.ldquoBe patientyou have to wait, many shops will be asking you to que and limiting the numbers going in.

title: nicola-sturgeon-considering-shopping-vouchers-help-retailers
story: Non-essential shops in  health board areas moving out of tier  lockdown restrictions can re-open from today, including in Glasgow.Northern Ireland is due to roll out a voucher scheme early in the new year, with qualying people to be given between pound and pound to spend in shops ndash but not online.David Lonsdale, the director of the Scottish Retail Consortium, said the fact Ms Sturgeon was mulling over the idea was ldquoencouraging, stressing that it could give a ldquomuch-needed shot in the arm to shops and other businesses during the normal post-Christmas lull in trade.He spoke after Ms Sturgeon confirmed the Scottish Government is ldquolooking at that and considering that.:Coronavirus Scotland: Christmas shoppers told not to flout travel banShe said: ldquoIt is something that is under consideration. Northern Ireland have recently announced an initiative of that nature, so we will look at their example as well.Mr Lonsdale said: ldquoIt is encouraging that Scottish ministers appear to have listened and are responding positively to our calls to consider the potential for a high street voucher scheme.ldquoThe retail industry and our high streets are facing profound challenges at the current time due to a combination of factors including pandemic-induced restrictions and economic downturn, which have weighed on consumer demand.ldquoIf a voucher along the lines envisaged for Northern Ireland is introduced here it could put money into peoplersquos pockets and help get the Scottish economy moving again, giving a much-needed shot in the arm to shops and other consumer-facing firms like eateries in the leaner months early in the New Year.ldquoOur hope is that any such voucher would trigger additional spending by shoppers and consumers beyond the value of the voucher transaction, creating an even larger economic multiplier.The SRC has already used its budget submission to the Scottish Government to call for a voucher scheme to be brought in.It also raised the issue directly with Ms Sturgeon at the Business in the Parliament conference last week.Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell said, in answer to a written parliamentary question, that ministers will ldquocontinue to weigh up the impacts that each scheme can have and ensure that the most effective support is targeted to support dferent sectors.

title: genetic-clues-covid
story: The team, from Edinburgh University, made the discovery by comparing the DNA of , patients in  intensive care units across the UK, against samples from health volunteers.They were able to pinpoint key dferences in five genes which partly explain why some people develop le-threatening symptoms from the infection, while others are unaffected.It could also offer clues as to why the virus wreaks such a devastating toll on certain families.Last month, -year-old grandmother Gladys Lewis, from Wales, and her two sons aged  and , died within five days of one another.In Northern Ireland, a mother, father, and son - who was in his s and worked for the health service in Belfast - also died in the space of two weeks between October and November.And in one of the worst reported tragedies to date, an outbreak claimed the lives of seven members of the same family in the US state of New Jersey in the space of a few weeks in March.: Patients % more likely to dieoperation takes place on surgeons birthdayDr Kenneth Baillie, the projectrsquos chief investigator and an academic consultant in critical care medicine, said: "It certainly is the case that genetic effects run in families, so its possible that that could explain these sorts of devastating events."Its also possible that there might be other, rarer gene mutations and well find them in the genomic sequencing, which is the next phase."The findings echo previous research done in the s which compared mortality from infectious diseases, cancer, and cardiovascular diseases among people who had been adopted.It revealed that people whose biological parent had died young from an infectious disease were six times more likely to succumb to an infectious disease also - eventhey had never met.The same was not true of cancer or cardiovascular disease, where the adopted persons risk dovetailed with their adoptive parents - but not their biological mother or father.While genes cannot influence exposure to pathogens such as respiratory viruses, they do affect how the body responds.: Radical one-stop-shop cancer diagnosis centres planned for ScotlandLe threatening Covid is an inflammatory lung disease which occurs when the bodys immune system overreacts to infection, attacking the hosts own tissues.The five genes identied by the Edinburgh University researchers are involved in two molecular processes: antiviral immunity and lung inflammation.Having highlighted the genes, the team were then able to predict the effect of existing drug treatments on patients, because some genetic iants respond in a similar way to particular therapeutics.For example, they showed that a reduction in the activity of one of the five genes -TYK - protects against Covid-.A class of anti-inflammatory drugs called JAK inhibitors, which includes the rheumatoid arthritis drug baricitinib, already produces this effect.They also discovered that boosting the activity of another of the five genes - INFAR - is likely to create protection by mimicking the effect of protein molecules which are released by immune system cells to defend against viruses.: What Scotland should learn from the disastrous unravelling of Wales firebreak successHowever, experts caution that - to be effective - patients might need the treatment early in disease.The researchers say that clinical trials should focus on drugs that target these specic antiviral and anti-inflammatory pathways.Dr Baillie, who is also a senior research fellow at the Roslin Institute, thanked the patients and their families for taking part.He added: ldquoThis is a stunning realisation of the promise of human genetics to help understand critical illness."Just like in sepsis and influenza, in Covid-, damage to the lungs is caused by our own immune system, rather than the virus itself."Our genetic results provide a roadmap through the complexity of immune signals, showing the route to key drug targets.ldquoOur results immediately highlight which drugs should be at the top of the list for clinical testing. We can only test a few drugs at a time, so making the right choices will save thousands of lives."The study is published in the journal, Nature.

title: brexit-supposed-controlling-borders
story: As it is, the UK had no sooner lsquotaken back controlrsquo by leaving the EU on January  than it promptly lost it again to a virus.It is one of the pandemicrsquos cruellest ironies that in the very time when public health would have benefitted most from this pull-up-the-drawbridge mentality that Westminster opted not to do so.Yet they have had no qualms with signing off on an immigration policy that, from January, will make it dficult for foreigners to enter the country for work unless they have a job lined up that pays at least pound, - ruling out many social care workers that our care sector so desperately needs.A joint report this week by the Care Inspectorate and Scottish Social Services Council, for example, showed that  per cent of care-at-home services and % of care homes for older people were reporting vacancies that were hard to fill at the end of  - months before the pandemic struck.: What Scotland should learn from the disastrous unravelling of Wales firebreak successMeanwhile, two other studies illustrated the fatal error of failing to lockdown our borders.One, by epidemiologists at the London School of Hygiene of Tropical Medicine, set out to investigate the impact imported cases on coronavirus outbreaks.In other words, what role does international travel play The paper, in the - fulltext" rel"nofollow"Lancet journal Public Health, estimated that the UK would have to reduce international arrivals by around % to bring imported cases down to less than % of the total Covid incidence, compared to % for France.Travel restrictions ldquohave clear benefits when there are zero or few cases in the destination country, noted the researchers, but ldquoonce case numbers within a country are sufficiently large that local outbreaks have been established and are self-sustaining, travel restrictions become less effective.Time is of the essence. Taiwan began inspecting plane passengers coming from Wuhan for signs of fever from December  - the same day that the World Health Organisation was first notied of a mysterious lsquoWuhan pneumoniarsquo.The island nation, which has had just seven Covid deaths in a population of nearly  million, banned travellers coming from Wuhan as of January  - two days after recording its own first Covid case. By February , all travellers from China were prohibited, with strict quarantines imposed on everyone .By contrast, the US decision to ban travellers from Europe as of March  ldquocame too late to prevent a large epidemic in New York already seeded mainly by European travellers.The UKrsquos problem was is that we only half shut the door after the horse had long bolted: international travel was strongly discouragedduring lockdown, with quarantine rules not introduced until June.: Anti-vaxxers are nothing new - but nor are medical cover-ups - so lets be honest about Covid vaccineEven then, people were ldquotold to self-isolate for  days on arrival, with promises of spot checks and pound fines, but monitoring was slow to get started and enforcement slight.Since June , nearly , people have entered Scotland from outside the UK, of whom ,have been required to quarantine.Of these, only , were earmarked to be followed up by contact tracers, but more than  could not be reached.Figures reported in October showed that  people were referred to the police by Public Health Scotland for potential breaches of quarantine by the end of August, but only one fine issued.Compare this to Australia, where borders have been closed since March exceptto Australian citizens and permanent residents.Even then, all international arrivals are escorted by police from the airport to a hotel where they must remain in their room for  days at a cost to themselves of AU,. Meals are ordered online and delivered to guestsrsquo doors, and there are fines for anyone caught breaching quarantine.To date, Australia has had  confirmed Covid deaths in a population of  million. Ironically,  were in the state of Victoria alone, where a second wave in August was linked to travellers in a quarantine hotel infecting staff due to lapses in infection control procedures.Scotland has had , Covid deaths in population of . million.We might not have control over UK borders, but the Scottish Government could have adopted more stringent quarantine controlsit chose.It might even have been wise to restrict cross-border travel with England.A genomic analysis led by Edinburghrsquos Roslin Institute for the UKs Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies makes clear that ldquotravel-associated importsfollowing the easing of lockdown are responsible for seeding the current epidemic population.: How did we end up back in lockdown  Just follow the numbersBy mid-July, the effects of lockdown had ldquoeliminated the majority of community transmissions in Scotland.Illustration showing strains of the Covid-causing coronavirus in circulation in Scotland during This would have been the moment to ramp up travel restrictions and quarantine instead summer holidays reignited a second wave.Between July  and August , there were  ldquoimport events from where into Scotland .Of these,  came from England,  from Europe, and four from Asia, with an ldquoapparent peak of imports in August.These were subsequently responsible for % of the viral strains circulating in the population from summer onwards - though European imports seemed to spread faster and accounted for twice as many infections as those brought from England.The hard lesson is that it is not enough to bring the virus under control through lockdown - you need strict curbs on movement afterwards to safeguard areas of very low prevalence.By doing so, we might have prevented many of the other restrictions we have faced on hospitality, retail and leisure - as Taiwan has.Instead, and ironically, the UK has paid the price for granting its citizens free movement.

title: holyrood-budget-leap-16m-next-year
story: In a submission to Holyroodrsquos finance committee, the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body , the parliamentrsquos cross-party board, said a . per cent budget hike was required.The increase will take the combined revenue and capital budget into nine figures, up from pound.m to pound.m.The budget for   had already been due for an above-inflation rise of pound.m, or .%, due to additional security measures and an election contingency fund of poundm.However a further pound.m is now needed, including pound.m for increased staff costs to cope with a surge in MSP casework during the Covid crisis, and pound.m to pay the Electoral Commission for work on the  Holyrood election and the  council elections.The latter is a new devolved responsibility.Earlier this week the SPCB said the ldquostaff cost provision for each MSP would rise from pound, to pound, next year to cover an additional full-time position.Some MSP offices are currently seeing  to  new cases each day.The SPCB also forecast a pound.m drop in its revenue and capital budget in  , but admitted this was ldquohighly caveated because of ldquocurrently unquantiable pressures, including wage and pension costs.A planned .% rise to the basic pound, wage for MSPs next year has already been scrapped as ldquowholly inappropriate given the economic pain caused by Covid.

title: snp-urged-end-secrecy-around-swirl-covid-business-support-schemes
story: The Scottish Tories said the figures must be published on a weekly basis, to cut through the confusion over a jumble of schemes at ious stages of delivery.Previous Treasury-funded, but council-run, business grants have already been published weekly.Ms Forbes this week announced a new poundm package for targeted Covid support across a we range of sectors, including taxi drivers, arts venues and travel agents.There will also be one-off payments to hospitality businesses of pound or pound in January to help them deal with the traditional post-Christmas dip in trade.The measures had a frosty response from business leaders.The Federation of Small Businesses in Scotland said it created ldquoa myriad of schemes at ious stages of delivery, with much of the cash unlikely to reach firms until the New Year.The Scottish Licensed Trade Association said the paltry one-off sums were an ldquoinsult to the industry in light of the ldquocataclysmic devastation it was facing.Scottish Chambers of Commerce said the poundm, while welcome, was ldquocold comfort to many businesses who have so little cash left they have only weeks to survive.It added: ldquoFor many, January will be too late to save business owners, their families and their employees from economic ruin.Tory MSP Maurice Golden said any support for our businesses was welcome, but the SNP must not shroud vital schemes in secrecy.ldquoWe must see an urgent guarantee that weekly data will be published on exactly where this funding has gone and how quickly it has got to businesses that are crying out for support, he said.ldquoThey routinely published business grants data earlier this year, but this is now not happening.ldquoThe concern is that SNP Ministers have got lost in too many schemes and are not on top of ensuring money is getting to where it is needed most.ldquoThe UK Government have made it possible for jobs and livelihoods to be protected across Scotland with almost pound billion worth of support. The SNP must not leave us in the dark as to how theyrsquove spent that funding.Labour said Ms Forbes should ldquocome clean over what proportion of business support funds had made it into the hands of employers.The party said the Government must also ensure firms got urgent support before new funds became available in January to stop them going to the wall over Christmas.Labour MSP Jackie Baillie said: ldquoThe SNP simply cannot abandon Scotlandrsquos businesses and the thousands of the workers that they employ to a winter of closures, unemployment and misery.ldquoThere is no sense in deferring support when thousands of businesses are at risk of going to the wall now. Business owners and the workers they employ havenrsquot the luxury to move at the languid pace of the SNP ndash they need help now.ldquoThe SNP must also, as a matter of urgency, make public the proportion of business support funds that have actually made it into the hands of businesses. There is no point grandstanding over the level of support you are offeringit is sitting, collecting dust, in the Scottish governmentrsquos bank account.ldquoBusinesses will be the dynamos of our economic recovery, but unless the SNP pulls the finger out now we will be left with a skeleton economy and spiralling unemployment. Itrsquos time for action.The Scottish Government said: ldquoWe are committed to transparency, and full information about grants paid under the Restrictions Fund which closed last month and the new Strategic Framework Business Fundwhich replaced it will be published shortly.ldquoThereafter wersquoll publish regular statistical updates on the SFBF and on the poundm package of extra winter support for business announced this week.ldquoAs the SFBF is paid four-weekly, there would be no merit in publishing weekly data for it.
