title: ‘An amazing feeling’
story: CASTLEWELLAN star Caitriona Caldwell has said the emptiness of the Kingspan Breffni Park stadium will be one of her abiding memories when she looks back on a weekend when she and her Down camog team-mates were crowned All-Ireland champions.Caldwell was part of a Down defence which helped to keep in check an Antrim attacking line as the Mourne girls clinched the title on Saturday.ldquoWhen the final whistle went and we knew we were champions, just the adrenaline, the buzz and sense of achievement was amazing, recalled Caitriona.ldquoIt was strange, there we were in the stadium in Cavan, a big stadium, but an empty one with this achievement of what we had just done. It was a bit surreal,no doubt.Down went into the game with the pain of a one-point semi-final defeat to Westmeath last term still very much in their minds.That was a heart-breaking reversal for the Mourne girls, but one that they were able to use to fuel their bid for glory this time around.Caitriona said that despite the stadium being bereft of fans the players knew there were so many cheering them on from afar.ldquoThe early goal at the start of the game really helped to settle us down, she said. ldquoIn those stages I was thinking of my mummy and the nerves she would be feeling watching us. But as a team, we needed to get switched on early, get those nervy jitters out of our system quickly, because we knew the challenge that Antrim would pose to us.ldquoEverything went great from early on in the game for us. The communication was good, the flow of the moves worked, and on the day thankfully it all clicked.She also told of how in the days leading up to the final the players spoken about the heartbreak of having come so close in the past. That was something that they knew they could not allow to happen again.ldquoWe did talk about the defeats and the funny thing is, in a way those defeats can actually work to spur you on a bit more, she revealed.ldquoIt played a big part for us psychologically for last weekend, especially for the older players on our . The older you get, you donrsquot know how much more often the chances will come around I suppose. For girls like Catherine McGourty and Fionnuala Carr, they have been there for such a long time, since I was a wee girl really.ldquoThe satisfaction that they must feel, having been there for thatof time, is probably a dferent type of satisfaction to what the younger players must be experiencing now in the wake of what we have done.ldquoAll of this has been a long time coming, but the progress of Down camogie for a while has been brilliant. The numbers participating are going up all the time, there is a great junior structure.ldquoEveryone who was in our team at the weekend, has bettered themselves as players and gone from strength to strength. The bond that has developed with us as team mates has been unbelievable.All of the Down camogie camp are also acutely aware of the wider positive impact their success has had on people within their own communities. With many people feeling the implications of the restrictions placed on le by coronavirus, it has been a dark time for many. Caitriona said she and her fellow All-Ireland winners feel very lucky.ldquoWe have been in a fortunate position. When I think back I suppose only a matter of weeks, none of us were really surewe would get much,any, camogie action for the remainder of the year.ldquoTo go from that, to being All-Ireland champions, it really is just dficult to put it into words what that means.ldquoCastlewellan has been brilliant in supporting us all the way too. I have had so many messages, both wishing me luck before the final and congratulations since. It shows how much our success has meant to the community.She added: ldquoThis year, of all years, we were lucky the championship even went ahead. To go from that position, to be sitting here now talking to people as an All-Ireland champion, well it just doesnrsquot get much better to be honest with you..prettyPhoto

title: A team effort%2C says Niamh
story: DOWNrsquoS Niamh Mallon has paid tribute to everyone in the successful camogie camp after they were crowned All-Ireland champions.Derek Dunnersquos side swept aside the challenge of Antrim in Saturdayrsquos showpiece in Cavan to clinch the Intermediate title for the first time since .The Portaferry player said the win had been a long time in coming with the final win secured by a group of players who have been together for almost a decade.ldquoWe have been on the road and this journey together for a long time, said Niamh. ldquoI suppose it hurt in the past couple of years how we came so close, but just couldnrsquot quite get the title. But after that hurt, I suppose the big thing now is relief.The win was the crowning of an unforgettable journey for Down camogs, led by their manager and Laois native Dunne, with Niamh explaining that it has been a year they will never forget.ldquoItrsquos a big win for all of us as iniduals but it was all about doing it for Down, said Niamh, playing down the crucial role she played in scoring two girls to propel her side to the coveted title.ldquoFor the two goals I was in the right place at the right time, she said. ldquoWe worked all week on how we would be able to get on top of Antrim. We knew they were young and a bit inexperienced, but a seriously talented team.ldquoWe knew we could not afford to let them into their stride but, I suppose, in that first half we were guilty of letting them do that a little bit. At half-time, it was about getting in, regrouping and we really drove home the game-plan and swamped the middle third of the pitch.Niamh said she and her team-mates were convinced that once they were able to open up a gap it could prove too much for the fledgling Antrim side to overcome.ldquoThat is what we hoped, she continued. ldquoIn many ways, we have been hurt by our results at this stage in the past, but it also does make you stronger and the experience we gained from the past undoubtedly was a help going into this final.ldquoThat was something we knew we had over Antrim and had to use to our advantage. We knew once we got that little edge on them on the scoreboard, we were on our way to the win.With the title secured, the Down camp can look forward to some well-earned rest and reflection over the Christmas period with Niamh admitting for a iety of reasons that it will be a year that will be impossible to forget.ldquoWithout any doubt it has been a mad year but,you know the Down camogie set-up, yoursquoll know we never do anything by half. Winning in  in a pandemic is just like us. Itrsquos great to get over the line with the win and great to get our hands on the title. We will enjoy this one for sure, she said.Having joined the squad as a gted -year-old in , Niamh has endured junior final reverses disappointment in  and  along with a number of her teammates, admitting that after knocking on the door it was terric to finally lt the title.She continued: ldquoWe won the junior title in  and a lot of girls then stepped away. We regrouped then in  and  and changed our approach this year. We didnrsquot look at the bigger picture and took it game by game. Obviously with the restructure after the pandemic you had to adapt and go again and we did and wersquore just delighted.Niamhrsquos scars of battle are very evident with a cut on the nose but the Portaferry sharpshooter is understandably unconcerned. She has spent more time in deeper roles this year, making her harder to pick up when drting inside to often stunning effect.This was evidenced on Saturday with - of her tally of - from play arriving within six minutes of Maeve Kellyrsquos magnicent th minute goal that gave Antrim the lead. That speaks of a big-game player, but Mallon reiterates her managerrsquos assertion that this a truly collective achievement.Modestly, Niamh doesnrsquot mention herself in her checklist of those the team used to lean too heavily upon, acknowledging the privilege of being allowed to congregate and socialise as elite sportspeople in the midst of COVID- when many are confined to their quarters.Niamh added: ldquoDown is no longer reliant on Sara-Louise Carr [Graffin], Fionnuala Carr and Karen McMullan ndash itrsquos an overall effort from  to  with the title win coming straight from the training ground.ldquoItrsquos been massively enjoyable and I have been based from home since the pandemic struck. From a camogie playing perspective itrsquos been great. Irsquove just been around home and able to train.ldquoWe havenrsquot taken for granted the situation we found ourselves in. We have been massively privileged as a lot of people have not had the opportunity to socialise like we did over the past couple of months. To enjoy it as much as we have and get silverware out of it at the end is class..prettyPhoto

title: Biden receives formal invite to visit district
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council is to formally invite incoming US President Joe Biden to the district.The local authority is to work alongside Louth County Council on the invitation which will be forwarded to the White House and the US Consulate in Northern Ireland.While the overwhelming majority of the districtrsquos politicians backed a proposal inviting Mr Biden to visit Newry and Downpatrick when the issue was debated on Monday night, DUP and Ulster Unionist councillors abstained during a vote on the issue.They argued that the motion was ldquopolitical and questioned why the council welcomed Mr Bidenrsquos election and that of incoming vice-president Kamala Harris when it had never before welcomed any political victory in the democratic world.The motion was tabled by Rowallane Alliance councillor Patrick Brown who said the new US president is fiercely proud of his Irish heritage and has close ties with the Cooley area in Co Louth.ldquoIt was a historic US election which took place during the unprecedented context of a global health crisis and we know that President Biden will have his hands full at the start of his term dealing with the Covid pandemic and subsequent economic recovery, he said.ldquoBut, given his strong ancestral links to this area, there is every possibility that he will visit Ireland at some point, as every president since Ronald Reagan has done, except Donald Trump. Mr Bidenrsquos links with the area are very recent and local.Cllr Brown said Mr Bidenrsquos great, great grandfather Patrick Blewett left Mayo in  to become a sailor in the USA, settling in Scrampton, Pennsylvania, while his great grandfather, James Finnegan, arrived in New York in the late s after travelling from Warrenpoint.He added: ldquoWhile Mr Biden visited Ireland as recently as , there is every reason why Ireland and the UK would be top of his travel list when circumstances allow. Mr Biden has unwavering support for the peace process, given the instrumental role his party played in bringing it together.ldquoWhat better place for the incoming president to visit than our district to trace his ancestral routes in Louth, visit the port his family emigrated from and see the resting place of St Patrick in Downpatrick.SDLP councillor Gary Stokes said the man who will become the th US president ldquoclearlyvalues his Irish heritage and believes thatthe local authority works alongside Louth County Council, there is a better chance of him visiting the Newry, Mourne and Down area.The DUPrsquos Glyn Hanna suggested that the incoming president had made himself a ldquoisive character with his ill-advised remarks about Orange and Green.He also argued that a man who has spent  years in politics was either badly briefed or totally ignorant of the situation in Northern Ireland, given his remarks which he should apologise for.Cllr Hanna added: ldquoMr Biden should stop looking through his Irish American tinted glasses and see the reality of the situation that there will not be a united Ireland without the consent of the people of Northern Ireland. I would suggest that he is reminded of this.UUP councillor David Taylor said the motion ldquotook the local authority into US politics which it had never done before, arguing that itrsquo was not a unorm view that everyone welcomed Bidenrsquos victory.ldquoThe incoming president and his vice-president are more than welcome in Northern Ireland at any time. The leader of the free world should be more than welcome to come here which could be beneficial from an investment point of view, he said.ldquoWe acknowledge Mr Bidenrsquos ancestral links to the area and it is not the case that we donrsquot welcome any US president.Sinn Feinrsquos Declan Murphy said that while he understood where his unionist colleagues were coming from, he did not necessarily agree with them.He said he was not supporting the motion for sentimental reasons, explaining it is primarily an opportunity for the island of Ireland to access the White House and to provide more leverage, as it has done in the past, when it comes to dealing with some dficult issues including legacy which politicians here have found it dficult to sort out.Cllr Murphy said he believes that Mr Bidenrsquos election provided ldquogreat opportunities for investment, particularly given the uncertain times ahead as a result of Brexit, adding: We are going to need all the support we can possibly get..prettyPhoto

title: Boost for Dunleath development plans
story: AMBITIOUS plans to redevelop Dunleath Park in Downpatrick as a centre of sporting excellence have taken a step forward.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council committee is to examine the proposal and is being encouraged to establish a project board to take the development further and unlock the facilityrsquos full potential.At Monday nightrsquos monthly meeting of the local authority, a proposal calling for the revitalisation of the huge sports facility was referred to the councilrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee for further debate and analysis.Politicians are being asked to establish a development plan that will include cycling and walking trails, the provision of new sensory gardens and upgrading existing sports pitches.The suggested project board mdash comprising council officials and Downpatrick area councillors mdash is expected to focus on all options, including the potential for a new G pitch and so-called bubble facility to allow outdoor tennis to continue in all weathers.Dunleath Park has been at the heart of local sport for many decades catering for soccer, gaelic football and hockey, but little cash has been spent on it, apart from annual maintenance costs.This week, three local politicians have called for the park, which is adjacent to Downpatrickrsquos poundm ultra-modern leisure centre, to be developed as a centre of sporting excellence, insisting that the work is regarded as a priority.Cllrs John Trainor, Gareth Sharvin and Dermot Curran say they recognise Dunleathrsquos potential has been lying untapped for too long, with the trio delighted that the future of the facility has now been formally included on the local authorityrsquos agenda.On Monday night, Cllr Trainor said he was delighted that the proposal for a project board to progress the development of Dunleath Park for sporting excellence, health and wellbeing and recreation was to be discussed by the Active and Healthy Communities Committee.ldquoThis is an essential next step in the development of Dunleath and Gareth, Dermot and I are incredibly proud to lead from the front here. Dunleath Park offers much potential which must be realised, he added.Cllr Sharvin said that given that the council had committed to the proposed development being included on its agenda, it was vital that a project board was appointed to focus on the development and identy key projects for Dunleath.He said local councillors appreciated the potential redevelopment of Dunleath Park has for Downpatrick and the importance of the site for sport in the area, particularly for the Downpatrick Youth Football League and several senior clubs who use the pitches.ldquoThere can be no question that this project board must be led by Downpatrick councillors, insisted Cllr Sharvin.ldquoWe were elected by the people of this area to represent them on council and that is exactly what we have been doing and will continue to do through this board.Cllr Curran cautioned that plans to redevelop Dunleath Park would not happen overnight as there were a number of obstacles that need to overcome.ldquoWe recognise the need for flood assessment for this location but are confident that there are local wins for the community to be had in the short term, he continued.ldquoThere is no reason why we could not develop a walking and cycling path around Dunleath while plans for the larger development continue. Therefore, we will now be writing to Communities Minister Caraacutel Niacute Chuiliacuten MLA to propose this and request funding.Cllr Curran said the Downpatrick councillors looked forward to updating ratepayers about the progress of their proposal, explaining this was why they would like a working group set up as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Centres could help rollout
story: LOCAL leisure centres could potentially play key roles in the rollout of the Covid- vaccine across the district.Health chiefs are drawing up plans for a huge logistical operation to vaccinate people with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.It is understood that a number of vaccination centres have been earmarked to help with the rollout of the vaccination programmes, including leisure centres and hospitals.It was revealed at Monday nightrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council that senior officials are liaising with health administrators in relation to the vaccination programme.Council chief executive Marie Ward said the organisation is ready to assist the South Eastern and Southern health trusts with a vaccination programmerequired.She also confirmed that the local authority is continuing to liaise with the Public Health Agency in relation to providing coronavirus testing facilities.Rowallane councillor Terry Andrews said that given the huge amount of work required to vaccinate people, the local authority had a number of venues, including leisure centres, which could play key roles in the operation.ldquoI would be very much in favour of council buildings being used to aid the rollout programme. In addition, I would be keen to see the Covid- testing programme expanded across the district.Cllr Andrews said while a long journey lay ahead in terms of testing people and ramping up the vaccination programme, the arrival of the vaccine was good news.Even so he encouraged people to continue to socially distance, wear a mask and adhere to public health advice.With the latest two-week lockdown due to end at midnight tomorrow, health officials have suggested that the number of new infections will decline and potentially remain stable before Christmas.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said Covid- remained at large across the community and urged people to continue to exercise caution and follow public health advice.With businesses due to reopen this Friday, she is encouraging people to shop local and support local traders, but to do so safely.ldquoWe know that there will be further relaxations around Christmas in terms of ious regulations and while we are asking people to enjoy the festive season, we want them to do safely, while adhering to the public health message, said the council chairwoman.ldquoThere is positive news of the vaccine but it is going to be some months before it is administered across a wide area, so for the sake of a few extra months, I appeal to people to please exercise that extra caution that is very much needed at this time..prettyPhoto

title: Chef Alex cooks up Christmas treats
story: DUNDRUM chef Alex Greene has emerged cream of the crop as he competes in the Great British Christmas Menu competition.The  year-old mdash who is the head chef of Deanersquos EIPIC restaurant in Belfast mdash will be seen in action on BBC  tonight as he cooks against past winners of the show.Alex has already got a stunning canape and starter through to a banquet to honour NHS frontline staff and other key workers for their dedication throughout the pandemic.While he got two dishes through to this yearrsquos Great British Menu banquet to mark  years of childrenrsquos literature, he was disappointed not to have be crowned Champion of Champions at the banquet.However, his already successful appearance in the current show has helped him come to terms with it.Alex told the Recorder that he will be appearing in every episode of the show which ends on Christmas Eve.ldquoI canrsquot say what  has happened obviously, but for me itrsquos been massive, even for the fact that it has a chef winner from every show on it, he said.ldquoThe whole thing of getting two courses to the banquet for two years running has never happened before, no other chef has ever done it.Alex said that he has met so many people since May who told him he should have won the Champion of Champions title.ldquoEven Chef Niall Keating, who won the title, has said to me that on three occasions diners at his restaurant who have tried his Great British Menu dishes told him that I should have won, he said.ldquoHe and I are very good friends now and the exciting thing for viewers is that some of the biggest names in food are still to come through the programme.Alex revealed that with the reopening of EIPIC over the summer, he only had just over three weeks to prepare for the competition.ldquoI was working on the showrsquos dishes just a week after opening the restaurant so there was a lot of things to juggle and it was an absolute stressor this year.The chef, who started off his career at the Buckrsquos Head in Dundrum also confirmed he has opened up a new shop, Fish and Farm, in Newcastle.ldquoI am literally not cooking anything, Alex said of the shop. ldquoI just wanted to open something in the town at the minute as I am planning to open something there next year.ldquoItrsquos just a fishmongerrsquos but I wanted to do it as Irsquom passionate about fishing. Itrsquos a local grocery store as well with everything in the shop from the island of Ireland and therersquos a cheese counter at the back. Itrsquos something a little more bespoke and dferent.He said his parents, Mark and Glynis, canrsquot keep up with the pace of his success this year.ldquoMy parents have told me that I need to stop now and take a bit of time to myself and enjoy things. But the whole family is proud and supportive.See Alex in tonightrsquos Great British Christmas Menu on BBC Two at pm..prettyPhoto

title: Down queens rule supreme
story: DOWN camogs lted the Liberty Insurance All-Ireland Intermediate Camogie Championship for the first time in  years with a commanding at Kingspan Breffni Park, Cavan, on Saturday.The star of the show was Niamh Mallon, who illustrated the full breadth of her array of talents as a well balanced Down made experience count, producing a power-packed second half performance.Mallon began at left half-forward, but it was no surprise to see her drting into full-forward for periods of play, a ploy that yielded signicant idends when the game was still there to be won. She was a key figure in Downrsquos success.The Portaferry ace claimed two goals and three points from play, and was a key figure in Downrsquos success.Down had too much firepower for Antrim, with Sara-Louise Graffin proving a very influential foil to Mallon. The likes of Sorcha McCartan, Lauren Clarke and Aimee McAleenan were selfless in their toil.Further back, Graffinrsquos sister Fionnuala Carr thundered into the fray in the last ten minutes of the first half.The -year-old marked her  years of representing Down at adult level in stirring fashion alongside fellow co-captain Karen McMullan.Former dual star McMullan was in Australia when Down lost the  final. However, she ed after three years away last term, when the Mourne women fell short by a point at the penultimate hurdle to subsequent victors Westmeath.They would not be denied this time around though, despite the shock of conceding a goal after less than  seconds.It took five minutes for Derek Dunnersquos side to regain their composure, but they were in front by the th minute after Mallon, McAleenan, Paula OrsquoHagan and Graffin all raised white flags.Antrimy hit four of the next five scores to establish a two-point advantage that could have been even greater had Catrine Dobbin not just dragged her ground shot wide with Catherine McGourty coming out quickly to narrow the angle.The Down response was notable. Three points came, including a wonderful effort by McCartan. Then, after Nicole OrsquoNeill pointed a free at the other end, Graffin hit the net with a goal in the third minute of first-half injury time. She showed tremendous strength to make space and finish in trademark fashion after brilliant play out wide by Clarke.That made it - to - at the interval but Paul McKillen got the ideal response from his Antrim team.Dobbin pointed early in the second half before Kelly drilled a fantastic goal home in the th minute.The -year-old took a shoulder from Dearbhla Magee with ease before unleashing a shot that was just too strong for Downrsquos custodian McGourty to repel.Drain denied McAleenan a quick riposte, but it came shortly after as Mallonrsquos piledriver ed her side to the lead. She followed up with a point, as did OrsquoHagan from a free.When Mallon concluded some deft footwork with a resounding finish after Clarke had done tremendously well to win possession, the writing was on the wall for Antrim.They continued to battle, but Down were dominant in too many sectors now.Their know-how shone through as they ensured that there would be no goals conceded, unafraid to relinquish frees to that end. OrsquoNeill converted a few but as time ran out, major scores were required.In the end, it was Clarke who raised the gamersquos final green flag, a fair reward for her tireless efforts.There could be no doubt about the merit of Downrsquos win however. They had done it at last, and the final whistle brought their celebrations.Down: C McGourty, C Caldwell, D Magee, D Harrison, K McMullan, F Carr, B Fitzpatrick, A Keown, P OrsquoHagan , S McCartan , S L Graffin , N Mallon , C Cowen, L Clarke , A McAleenan .Subs: C Rocks for Fitzpatrick , C Fitzpatrick for Cowen , I OrsquoHare for Clarke .Antrim: E Boyle, C Patterson, C Drain, C Conlon, N Donnelly, M Connolly, A Boyle, E Laverty, L McNaughton, Christine Laverty, M Kelly , C Dobbin , R McCormick , Ciara Laverty, N OrsquoNeill . Subs: C McKillop for E Laverty , O OrsquoHara for Ciara Laverty , N A Donnelly for Patterson , A Donnelly for Christine Laverty .Referee: J Heffernan .Down -Antrim -ALL-IRELAND INTERMEDIATE FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum looking assuredly to future
story: DUNDRUM Cricket Clubrsquos newly appointed player coach says he is excited about the prospects for the club, particularly at youth level.Daniel Kearsley, signed from Bridnorth in Shropshire, is a Level Two ECB coach and will be involved in all aspects of coaching at the club, from juniors through to seniors.He will also be involved with coaching in local primary schools, together with the annual finals day at the Meadow.The  year-old is a fine fast bowler, who has had trials at Warwickshire and Nottinghamshire, and is excited about coming to play in Dundrum.Daniel says he has been familiar with Dundrum Cricket Club for quote some time.ldquoI first built a relationship with the club on they came to Shropshire on a senior tour in . They were to play Madeley CC, but they were a couple players short, so me and my brother Liam offered to play.ldquoFast forward two years to June this year, and my brother had been in contact with the club about us moving over. Being able to see the club and watch a couple matches was great, especially seeing the talent the club has was wonderful.ldquoA few weeks had passed, and I knew there was an opportunity for me to come over for the  season, it was something that I debated due to the season I had at Bridgnorth CC. I wanted to build something special at Dundrum, while also improving my coaching experiences.ldquoDundrum has the potential to be a real driving force and coming over is something Irsquom very excited to have the opportunity to do.ldquoIt is especially exciting with the newly-formed third XI which will be great for the younger players coming through. The club has a great feel to it with the players, coaches and the people behind the scenes which is incredibly important to be a successful club.Daniel says he is enthusiastic about what the club can achieve in the near future. ldquoThe club has a great set-up already with the juniors, and the talented youngsters in the ranks.ldquoMy main goals for the juniors this year are to get as many coming to training and summer camps as possible. Youth cricket is all about having fun and getting out to enjoy yourself, so increasing the number of juniors coming through is going to be great.ldquoWithin the junior set-up, I also want to be forming an Emerging Players Programmefor juniors aged - that have got the potential to push for the chances to play senior cricket. This would be the stepping stone of junior to senior cricket, which I believe a lot of clubs donrsquot take into account.ldquoThe EPP would be a group of seven or eight juniors that receive an extra session during the week where we can focus on developing skills further, this would run for three to four weeks which would then be looked at to decidedferent juniors deserve to be in.ldquoMy other goals are getting juniors, where deserving, pushing for the third  spots during the season. This would be fantastic to see.Daniel, who will work closely with Dundrumrsquos chairman of selectors Jeff Maguire, also has plenty of plans on how to make improvements within the senior side. ldquoOne of my goals for the senior teams this year is getting match-winners throughout the club. This is important for a season where promotion is definitely what the club should be looking at, and also making selection dficult for the right reasons. ldquoAs a tactically-based cricket coach, this is something Irsquoll be looking to bring into the first  during training and matches.ldquoPlayers knowing their roles within the team is vital to the understanding of winning and putting in good performances, so helping the players understand their own game is a real goal.ldquoBeing available for players to book one-on-ones will be a great chance for players to work on the smaller details in their game, which is something that can break the barrier to the next level of their game.He added: ldquoOverall I just want everyone associated with the club, from the players to the parents, to be enjoying some great cricket and watching the club go from strength to strength..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C December 13%2C 2000
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash It was lights, camera and action at Downpatrick Railway Museum last week with the shooting of a new pound. million movie.With cameras rolling, flood lights glaring and well known actors walking around, the station could have been mistaken for a Hollywood set.Two scenes from the film lsquoPuckoonrsquo, based on the book by Spike Milligan, were shot last Tuesday evening at the railway.A member of Downpatrick Railway Society, John Keenan, plays the stationmaster in one of these scenes, opposite well known actor and comedian Grf Rhys Jones who plays a character called Major Stokes.Major Stokes is waiting for his platoon to arrive from Belfast and during the scene he has a heated argument with the station master while waiting for the train to arrive.Mr Keenan, a great Railway Museum supporter, said he was delighted to be Station Master of the railway at long last.ldquoIt was a splendid opportunity to play the station master. The station looked fantastic and many of the visitors who hadnrsquot been there before were very impressed by the museum, he said.The film is a comical interpretation of the partition of Ireland set in the fictional town of Puckoon in .KILLOUGH ndash Christmas is going to be that little bit extra special in the home of a starry-eyed Killough toddler this year thanks to the medical staff at the Downe Hospital.Just over a month after his mother rushed him to the hospital after he became seriously ill, Conor Chillingworth is now back in his Kennedy Park home patiently waiting for Santa Claus to arrive.But it could all have been so dferent. Celine Dornan is convinced that had it not been for the doctors and nurses at the Downpatrick hospital, her son, who suffers from a rare genetic disorder, would not be alive today.She believesthe local hospitalrsquos accident and emergency department had not been so close to her home, Conor, who suffered a convulsion almost four weeks ago, would not have survived what she has described as a ldquonightmare journey to a hospital in Belfast.The toddlerrsquos relieved mother has this week paid a glowing tribute to the medical staff at the Downe and urged the Department of Health to do all it can to retain lesaving services in the area.SAUL ndash Education officials have this week confirmed St Patrickrsquos Primary School in Saul is to be replaced with a new state-of-the-art building.The construction of the new school has been given ldquohigh priority status in the Department of Educationrsquos capital planning list and work on the scheme could start some time next year.A site has already been identied, but its location is being kept a closely guarded secret until a project manager is appointed to oversee the new development.The Council for Catholic Maintained Schools is to meet shortly to help choose the new project officer with the appointment expected to help pave the way for the compilation of a detailed feasibility study and economic appraisal.News that a new school will be constructed in Saul in the near future has been confirmed by South Down MP, Eddie McGrady.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Cross community groups in Ballynahinch have this week pledged their support for the forthcoming peace walk in the town.They are delighted the event will take place just a few days before Christmas to provide local people with an opportunity to promote the positive image of le in Ballynahinch.The organisers of the walk say the December  event is designed to show those responsible for escalating sectarian violence in the town that their actions will not be tolerated and arfe simply not acceptable.Mr Gerry Crawford, of the Langley Road Community Association, and Mr Nat Morrison, of the Hillfoot Windmill Gardens Community Association, believe the peace walk could not have come at more opportune time.ARDGLASS ndash Fty years ago, a group of enterprising women in the Ardglass area invited countrywomen to join them in forming a new branch of a thriving association.Last Wednesday almost  members of Ardglass Womenrsquos Institute enthusiastically celebrated their golden anniversary at the Courtside Restaurant in Downpatrick.Their invited guests included Mrs Joan Shanks, chairman of the Federation of Womenrsquos Institutes of Northern Ireland, together with the presidents of the Quoile Area Group, former Executive members and former presidents of the Ardglass branch.During the evening, Mrs Shanks presented the current president of Ardglass Womenrsquos Institute, Mrs Avril Burgess, with a beautul piece of Limerick lace, designed as a map of Northern Ireland and mounted in a glass tray. This tray will be used in future years for needlework competitions.KILLYLEAGH ndash Down Council chiefs have this week been urged to bring forward an important meeting to discuss safety measures at a river in Killyleagh.Rowallane area councillors are due to meet early in the New Year to discuss measures to improve safety at the Dibney River, close to the Braeside housing estate in the town.But local community worker, Mr Billy Walker, says the meeting must take place as soon as possible with the safety measures put in place as a matter of urgency.Earlier this year, a young boy almost drowned after toppling into the river which was high as a result of heavy rainfall.Mr Walker said that given the recent poor weather and the huge rise in the level of the river, it is important major improvements are provided.Council chiefs are currently carrying out a risk assessment, which is due to be discussed at the New Year meeting, but Mr Walker has appealed to the council to bring the talks forward.DRUMAROAD ndash Drumaroad residents battling to save their parish hall are hoping to reach a compromise with the priest who planned to demolish it.Parishioners have been given breathing space to try and come to an agreement with Fr John Moley, after they secured a temporary court injunction preventing the premises being demolished.A number of residents have volunteered to form a working party who will represent the community in an active campaign to retain the  year-old building.The group is due to meet with Fr Moley next week with a number of proposals which will hopefully safeguard the future of the former dance hall in the heart of the village.Hundreds of parishioners crowded into Slieve Croob Inn at Seeconnell on Monday night to meet with a number of delegates who had been elected to speak with Fr Moley last week following a mass protest outside the hall.GAA ndash GAA clubs throughout Down have been told to clean up their disciplinary act, or  face the consequences.The stark warning was issued by county chairman Eamon OrsquoToole at Sundayrsquos annual Down convention in Newcastle.He told delegates that they should take a strong stand in discipline within their clubs and on the playing side.There were a number of unsavoury incidents during the year which were of no credit to the iniduals, clubs concerned and to the GAA in Down.ldquoI will continue to seek improvement andthere are serious misdemeanours I will expect the referees and appropriate committees to take the required action. To do otherwise would be an abdication of all our responsibilities. I will not turn a blind eye, he warned.Mr OrsquoToole, who was ed unopposed, said clubs should be run in a professional manner in accordance with best practice as recommended in the ious courses and officer manuals..prettyPhoto

title: Further strike action ahead
story: FURTHER strike action by council workers is planned for the New Year.Trade unions say that members are ldquoresolute in continuing their protest against Newry, Mourne and Down District Council over pay and conditions.The council is to be notied later this week of further planned strike action along with a possible overtime work ban or a work to rule instruction in place.A special full council meeting to discuss the matter will be held within the next few weeks to discuss the current impasse.Thousands of rate-payers across the district were affected when bins were not collected last Thursday, with many still waiting this week for their bins to be emptied.The council advised householders on social media to keep their bins at the kerbside until collected.It added: ldquoWe apologise for any inconvenience and would ask the publicto remain patient as we work through the backlog of missed collections. Please note that recycling bins containing wrong materials will not be collected.Workers manned pickets outside Downshire Civic Centre and the councilrsquos Strangford Road depot in Downpatrick and at sites in Newry.Administrative workers also joined in the strike and did not process any new applications for wedding or burials received that day.GMB regional organiser Alan Perry this week described the strike and its impact on ratepayers as ldquoregrettable but stressed that workers remained determined.He said: ldquoThe strike was highly successful but also highly regrettable that we have got into that situation where members have to take to the street.lsquoWe believe we can get a resolution but it takes management to engage with us. Our members are very much resolute and are quite prepared to take further days of actionrequired.Last night a council spokesperson said: Talks between Newry, Mourne and Down District Council and the joint trade unions, conciliated by the Labour Relations Agency are currently ongoing. Therefore, no further comment can be provided at this time.The strike went ahead despite the councilrsquos offer to increase pay scale of refuse workers employed by the former Down District Council to match those employed by the former Newry and Mourne District Council area.However, in a joint trade union side statement, GMB, Unite, NIPSA and SIPTU representatives laid the blame for the ldquoavoidable industrial dispute at the feet of council management.The statement said: ldquoThe trade unions engaged with the council management team in last minute and intense talks mediated by the Labour Relations Agency to seek a resolution to this dispute.ldquoWhile some progress was made in relation to job evaluation, job deions and a timetable for the completion of the negotiations, we failed to secure what was needed in relation to pay equality.ldquoThe point in contention is that for those workers whose pay grades are re-evaluated upwards, they will lose all pay progression accrued and will start at the bottom of the new grades.A statement issued last week by the council refuted that management had failed to engage and said it had met with trade unions, conciliated by the Labour Relations Agency , several times last month.It said that management presented proposals to the trade unions which would mean all refuse collection employees being employed on the same pay grades.It added: ldquoUnder the proposals, refuse workers in the former Down District Council area would increase to pay scales matching those in the former Newry and Mourne District Council area. Acceptance of these proposals could see wages for refuse workers in Downpatrick increasing from December , which has since been ratied.ldquoThe councilrsquos management also agreed to negotiate on additional payments to refuse employees in both Newry and Downpatrick for implementation of new Refuse Operating Procedures and associated practices, which would standardise working practices across the entire district. Pending negotiated agreement, existing practices and associated payments will remain unchanged.The council said that while it regretted that the trade unions were unwilling to call off the strike, it respected the right to take industrial action.The statement ended: ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down District Council remains fully committed to resolving this dispute, to ensuring fair pay, transparency and equality for all its employees and to delivering value for money for all rate payers in the Council area, especially at a time when many are experiencing signicant financial hardship.ldquoThe council will continue to work with the LRA and to engage in dialogue with the trade unions to find a workable solution as quickly as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Gateway plans to be submitted
story: A BUSINESS case for a flagship tourism project in Newcastle is due to be submitted within weeks.The multi-million pound Mournes Gateway initiative features a series of ambitious proposals including a gondola ride into the heart of the mountains.The proposal is one of several hoping to secure money under the Belfast City Regional Deal, with the Gateway project designed to signicantly enhance future tourist provision in Newcastle.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is one of six partners working under the city deal umbrella which are are hoping for a share of a near poundbn investment package.City deals are packages of funding and decision making powers which allow councils to boost the economy through the development of large projects in their respective areas.In addition, the deals are designed to allow councils to take charge and responsibility of decisions that affect their area, do what they think is best to help businesses grow, create economic growth and decide how public money should be spent.An outline business case for the Mournes Gateway project is to be formally submitted shortly along with a number of others from across the province.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is one of five councils paired with Belfast City Council, universities and the private sector who have committed poundm to help deliver a raft of schemes, with the remainder of the cash expected to come from the Treasury and Northern Ireland Executive.A  which has been appointed to oversee the development of the respective business cases met recently and has revealed that plans for an poundm regional investment are nearing ldquoan important milestone.The  members say the submission of the respective business cases to the UK and Northern Ireland governments in just a few weeksrsquo time represents an important milestone in the city deal journey so far.The UK government plans to invest poundm into the Belfast Region mdash which includes Newry, Mourne and Down mdash with a further co-investment of poundm from city deal partners, including the local authority.Last May, the NI Executive confirmed that it is providing match funding of poundm with the local authority hoping to secure poundm from this funding pot, with plans to add poundm of ratepayers money to fund the proposed gondola ride and visitor centre at the old quarry at Thomasrsquo Mountain.Council officials are also working alongside Tourism NI to secure financial backing for other aspects of the tourism initiative which includes an Alpine coaster ride enabling people to hurtle down the side of the mountain on a single track in a buggy.Other aspects of the tourism scheme include an elevated tree top walk in Tollymore Forest Park, a new visitor centre and bird hide at Murlough Nature Reserve and a new bridge constructed under the main Kilkeel Road at the Bloody Bridge on the outskirts of the town.There are also proposals to reduce the the tree line in Donard Forest on the slopes of the Mournes and the development of a so-called green travel network which would allow visitors to hire bicycles and electric bikes to make their way round ious attractions.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said the city deal was ldquocritical to the future recovery of the region.She continued: ldquoImportance has been placed on ensuring the progression of those projects that will stimulate transformative investment right across the city deal region, with the submission of the business cases taking us one step closer to the delivery phase and investment starting to flow into our region.ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council has worked towards the completion of outline business cases on the Mournes Gateway and Newry city centre regeneration scheme as part of this progress. ldquoAlongside these projects is the progression of Newryrsquos southern relief road, a high quality, digitally enabled innovation space and a robust employability and skills programme that will ensure we have the people and skills to drive future growth and investment.She added: ldquoThe proposals taken forward by the local authority are critical to ensuring that it unlocks investment and implements the organisationrsquos strategic priorities which will aid the districtrsquos recovery..prettyPhoto

title: Groups urged to apply for control of laneways
story: TWO leading organisations have been asked to formally adopt a series of laneways in Downpatrick.The appeal to take responsibility for the laneways mdash that link Church Street with the Malone Heights housing development mdash has been issued to Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Department for Infrastructure by local councillor Cadogan Enright.He said Breenrsquos Lane is one of two rights of way serving the general Malone Heights area, connecting Church Street with Malone Park and Malone Court and saving residents timewalking into the town centre by cutting out New Bridge Street.Cllr Enright said Breenrsquos Lane is particularly used by post-primary students going to school or residents doing a bit of shopping in the town centre who do not want to take their car.He explained that he has been attempting to persuade either the local authority or government department to clear up Breenrsquos Lane and maintain it.ldquoThis particular area is currently blocked as the result of some fly-tipping of mostly green waste from an abandoned site further up the path. I donrsquot believe that it was never adopted as it was cleaned in the past, but is now covered in moss and green debris which says to me that it has not been cleaned in over a year, suggested Cllr Enright.The Downpatrick councillor said that Harryrsquos Loney, which links the Strangford Road with Malone Heights and the Saul Road, has been adopted, describing it as a ldquovery useful short cut, especially for students who attend St Patrickrsquos Grammar School.Cllr Enright said the laneway was adopted last year after he spent many months trying to persuade Northern Ireland Water to maintain the sewer that runs through it which overflowed every time there was heavy rain.He added: ldquoThese laneways, or loneys as they are commonly described as, are not only an essential resource for local people, but are part of our sustainable future.ldquoToo many of them have been allowed to wane or be lost over the past  years as people adapted to taking even short trips by car. It is essential that these laneways are all adopted and maintained to encourage people to walk more and have a healthier lestyle.Breenrsquos Lane resident Robbie Hughes said that when the Malone Heights housing development was built, the laneway linking it with Church Street was surfaced with tarmac, with the work carried out to a high standard.He said the laneway should have been adopted with all the other pavements and roads in this area at the time and cannot believe that it was not.Mr Hughes said thatthe lanewayrsquos tarmac surface was not cleaned, it could become dangerous..prettyPhoto

title: History maker
story: A DUNDRUM nurse became the first person in Ireland mdash north or south mdash to get the Covid- vaccine yesterday.Joanna Sloan will now lead the vaccination programme in Belfast in the first decisive step in the battle to beat the coronavirus.The  year-old nursing sister received the first Pfizer BioNTech vaccine just before she started work at the Belfast Trust vaccination centre.A round of applause broke out at the Royal Victoria Hospital as a colleague injected her arm.The mother-of-one said that the moment was both emotional and important, not only to her personally but to people all over Northern Ireland.ldquoIt felt great honestly, a bit emotional but absolutely fine, Sister Sloan said.ldquoI just thought to myself, at last, we are here mdash through everything that healthcare workers hellipeither in hospital or community [have gone through], people themselves losing family members, us losing colleagues.ldquoIt just felt like a huge moment, that this could possibly be the final hurdle in the fight against Covid. It did not feel any dferent than any other immunisation that I have had, I did not feel any pain.The nurse said that the arrival of the vaccine was met by relief from herself and healthcare colleagues.ldquoItrsquos been long awaited. Therersquos been a lot of hard work to get this point. We are very, very grateful, she added.Sr Sloan said she hoped to share the moment with her five-year-old daughter, Cailie.ldquoI honestly hope that I get to be there when she sees it, she said. ldquoI hope that it makes her proud. I hope that she goes to school tomorrow and be proud that her mum has got the vaccine and was the first to get it. Irsquom excited to tell her and show her.The nurse said that her little girl was very aware of how hard she had been working over the past few months working to care for people with the virus and to prevent them getting it.Having worked this year in the Emergency Department of RVH as well as the Covid- testing centre, Sr Sloan revealed that she postponed her wedding this year due to the pandemic.She urged those who are first to get vaccinated to continue to maintain all recommended public health guidance.ldquoI would advise that even people who receive the vaccine today and in the next few months to still maintain all guidance with regards to social distancing, wearing face covering in public, PPE in a health care setting. Itrsquos vitally important that we try our best, not only to get vaccinated but to protect others around us.Sr Sloan acknowledged the advice from NIrsquos Chief Medical Officer, Dr Michael McBride, that it still wasnrsquot knownthe new vaccine could prevent those vaccinated spreading the virus to others.ldquoThat is why it is absolutely vital to keep washing your hands, keep your face covered and try and minimise the amount of contact with other people, she said.ldquoYou may still pick it from door handles in shops, work environment, or in shops and carry it home and vice versa.The senior nurse is a member of Dundrum GAC which recently praised her dedicated work during the year..prettyPhoto

title: Lidl’s new £3m store approved
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council planners have formally issued outline approval for new poundm Lidl supermarket in Newcastle.The decision was issued last week after the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee recently backed a plannersrsquo recommendation to approve the multi-million pound development.The leading retailer is to redevelop the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site in the town with the proposal including a new pound, base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team.Lidl plans to demolish the former school building to pave the way for the new store and rescue centre and parking for  vehicles, with planners insisting that no development activity or demolition work, ground preparation or vegetation clearance can take place until a final construction and environmental management plan has been submitted and approved by the Planning Authority.Plans to redevelop the former primary school site mdash which is expected to create up to  new jobs mdash were originally submitted in January  to replace Lidlrsquos existing base at Railway Street in the resort.Last November, it was announced that planning permission for the multi-million pound store was to be quashed following a judicial review by objectors.It was confirmed at the time that permission was quashed as the result of a procedural error in relation to the papers before the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal, with Lidl consistently arguing that its current base is too small to allow the store to carry the companyrsquos full range of goods, highlighting issues with narrow aisles and inadequate parking provision.Lidl said the Railway Street premises were only supposed to be a temporary home until a larger unit could be found, with Lidl insisting that it has been looking for an alternative town centre site for over decade without success until the Shanslieve Drive site became available.A number of objections were lodged with planners about the proposal, including that the development was not in keeping with the residential nature of the area and that the closure of the retailerrsquos existing store would have a detrimental impact on Newcastle town centre and surrounding inconvenience stores.Concern was also expressed about the proposed storersquos impact on traffic, the potential for increased flooding and the impact of selling alcohol, particularly to young children, with objectorsarguing that Lidlrsquos proposal was contrary to planning policy, was not in the interests of the community and would impact on the residential amenity of Shanslieve Drive residents.Conditions attached to the outline approval include the net retail floorspace of the new store shall not exceed , square metres and that no goods or merchandise will be stationed or displayed in the forecourt.Opening hours are limited to am to pm from Monday to Saturday and from pm to pm on Sundays, with store deliveries not permitted between pm and am with onsite floodlighting only operational between these hours..prettyPhoto

title: Maureen’s CD raises hundreds for Guide Dogs NI
story: SONGS from the childhood of Ballyhornan woman Maureen Gill-Sharp have raised pound, for Guide Dogs Northern Ireland.The money was raised as proceeds from Mrs Gill-Sharprsquos new CD of old Irish songs recalled from her childhood.The CD mdash I Stand on a Lonely Seashore mdash has proved to be a hit with local people as only a small quantity of the CD remains available.Known for her popular books, Moonlight on Ballyhornan Bay and Memoirs of a Ballyhornan Girl, Mrs Gill-Sharp previously raised over pound, for the charity, enabling her to name and sponsor a trainee guide dog puppy called Thomas.The CD has both local historical connections for Mrs Gill-Sharp, who is in her late eighties, as well as close emotional ones.The CD cover shows a young Maureen on the shore at Ballyhornan in the s.ldquoMany of the songs were learnt on my motherrsquos knee and at Dunsford school in Chapeltown many years ago, she explained.ldquoSo I knew the words off by heart at a very early age. To this day I can remember the songs very well and sing them often. A number of people over the years have asked me for the words and the air to some of the old songs, many of which they had never heard before.Naturally, her home village is included in the collection with the inclusion of the song, Ballyhornan in the Old County Down.One of the famous songs connected to a local place is Irsquom Sitting on the Stile Mary, a poignant song written by Lady Dufferin of Killyleagh.Mrs Gill-Sharp is delighted to have been able to support Guide Dogs NI once more.ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone who purchased a copy of the CD. A cheque for pound, has been sent to the Guide Dogs NI headquarters in Belfast.ldquoMany thanks also to all those who purchased a copy of the book Memoirs of a Ballyhornan Girl or who made a donation for the open garden. ldquoUnfortunately we were unable to run an lsquoOpen Gardenrsquo event this year due to the coronavirus restrictions, but we hope to be able to run the event next year all being well.To buy a CD or book, visit www.ballyhornan or the Guide Dogs NI Facebook page..prettyPhoto

title: MYMY in Stormont talks to purchase Ardnabannon
story: TALKS were held with a senior Stormont minister yesterday in a bid to ensure that a proposal by a local charity to purchase the former Ardnabannon outdoor pursuits centre is not derailed by the Education Authority.Mind Yourself and Your Matemdash currently based in Newcastle mdash is keen to secure the former outdoor pursuits centre near Castlewellan which was closed by education chiefs in  as part of controversial cost-cutting proposals.The -bed Ardnabannon facility was one of a number of outdoor residential centres in Northern Ireland to close following a rationalisation review.MYMY is a counselling organisation with extensive experience in suicide prevention and intervention which was formed  years ago by a number of bereaved family members and volunteers.The charity, which does not receive any government funding and relies solely on community donations, had an application to buy the Ardnabannon facility initially accepted by the Education Authorityfollowing discussions with the Department for Education, subject to confirmation that MYMY had the funds to complete the sale.The charity was working to secure funding and a business plan to pave the way for the acquisition of the iconic building and had hoped to have the finance in place by October next year ahead of completing the purchase in March .However, Stormont education minister Peter Weir has ruled that given the current economic circumstances there is no certainty that the MYMYrsquos business case would be approved or that funding would ldquoactually materialise to underpin the charityrsquos bid.In a letter to Newry, Mourne and Down councillors, Mr Weir said that in these circumstances, the EA would be left with a depreciating asset that it still owns a year further on.The education minister revealed that the EA is spending almost pound, a year on rates for the vacant Ardnabannon and that as some of the buildings at the sprawling site enjoy protected status, maintenance costs may also be incurred, alongside the risk of further damage caused by the weather or vandalism.ldquoMy department is operating under a constrained capital budget and to supplement this, income from the disposal of surplus assets is reinvested in the education estate to improve facilities for pupils, Mr Weirrsquos letter continues.He said in these circumstances he is content that Ardnabannon should be disposed of on the open market to realise the best , insisting that putting the complex up for sale does not mean that a purchase is imminent as it will depend on market interest.Mr Weir added: ldquoShould MYMY be in a position to confirm availability of funding ahead of any future sale, the Department would consider their offer in the round with others that come forward.At Monday nightrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council it was confirmed that charity officials have met with Stormont finance minister Conor Murphy with MYMY representatives due to meet communities minister Caral Niacute Chuiliacuten yesterday.Local politicians say that they are keen to see the former outdoor education centre to be redeveloped for community use.Cllr Andrew McMurray paid tribute to his colleagues for backing MYMYrsquos bid and hopes there is ldquostill scope for manoeuvre as far as the interested parties are concerned.ldquoI pay tribute to all councillors calling for this property to be handed back to the community in some shape or form, he added.Cllr Roiacutesiacuten Howell highlighted MYMYrsquos ldquoabsolutely fantastic work across the district and said itrsquos really disappointing that the charity is not being given an opportunity to raise the funds and that itrsquos business case was not looked at.She said Sinn Fein had facilitated the meeting with Mr Murphy and yesterdayrsquos meeting with Ms Ni Cuhiuliacuten.Cllr Howell added: ldquoThis is a fantastic building and MYMY does great work. The decision by Mr Weir is totally unreasonable and needs to be looked at again.Cllr Hugh Gallagher said he was disappointed with the content in the education ministerrsquos letter, describing the Ardnabannon centre as a vital part of the community.He added: ldquoIf this building was to be utilised it could provide a fantastic package for the local and wider community as it offers so much scope..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle singer releases festive single
story: A NEWCASTLE singer and songwriter has released a new track to raise awareness around homelessness and loneliness during the festive season.Stephen Rafferty, has always had a passion for music and first learned to play guitar when he was . He started gigging three years later in local cafes and now has a fan base of thousands.Stephen revealed that a family bereavement last year opened his eyes to loneliness, inspiring the new track entitled lsquoConcrete Christmasrsquo which has been months in the making, alongside working on an album about mental health problems in young people.He started writing his new song last December, explaining that two years ago his stepdadrsquos father passed away, with last Christmas the first one he had seen his stepdadrsquos mum on her own.ldquoWe were all sitting around the table and it seemed great. We were all having a few drinks and a laugh, but then I realised she would be going home on Christmas night on her own, he explained. ldquoThat really hit hard for me, that this is the first year of her whole le that she would be alone.ldquoAnd I thought,that is what it feels like for someone to lose one person, then how must it feel for someone to lose everything Stephen started writing the new track in the lead up to last Christmas but didnrsquot want to rush it, so he put the finishing touches to it in the summer.He said he knew that he wanted to record the song and hopes that it can spark an important conversation.ldquoI know people are upset about the pubs closing or not getting to their favourite restaurant, but there are people who donrsquot have a warm home to go to at night. This song puts things into perspective, Stephen continued.ldquoA little can go a long way, especially for local, home grown charities who do amazing ground work, specically during the colder months andanyone could donate to the likes of the Simon Community, Shelter NI, Belfast Homeless Services and The Welcome Organisation in Belfast after hearing this song it would be amazing.Stephenrsquos new song was was released on November  and has had hundreds of views and downloads to date, with emotional words telling the tale of sleeping on a concrete floor during the festive period alongside a hard hitting music video have made the song a success online in just a few days.Alongside Steven Fearnley, who owns Narrow Water Studios, and Mark Nugent, who directed the music video, Stephen also worked with musicians from George Ezrarsquos brass section.He hopes to launch his new album next summer and that Covid restrictions permitting, organise a gig. He said each song on the album has its own point about mental health and is based on his own personal experiencesldquoWe are hoping that we can get the release for next summer and do a proper one with all the musicians who have been involved, he continued. ldquoHopefully, with the Covid- vaccine on the way, next year will be dferent for music events and concerts.ldquoThroughout lockdown I streamed live gigs on Facebook and they were great. The views kept growing each week and people seemed to really enjoy them. I suppose lockdown did stop a lot of things for people, so it was good to be able to bring music to peoplersquos homes.Thanking everyone who has supported him throughout his musical career, Stephen said a huge lsquothank yoursquo to his friends, family and girlfriend Aileen for their constant support.He added: ldquoI really do appreciate every person who has listened to my songs and waited for my new material to come out. There is more to come.lsquoConcrete Christmasrsquo is available on Spoty, Apple Music iTunes and Amazon Music..prettyPhoto

title: Prizewinning author Dara to release new book
story: NATURE lover Dara McAnulty is set to end  on an incredible high with the news that his second book will be published next summer.The  year-old from Castlewellan has secured a two-book deal with publisher Macmillan Childrenrsquos Books.Wild Child is aimed at readers from seven years up and will be a family friendly guide to British and Irish nature.Itrsquos the latest achievement for the A-level student from Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle.The youngest ever winner of the Wainwright Prize for nature writing the and youngest author long-listed for the Baillie Gford Prize, Dararsquos debut book, Diary of a Young Naturalist, won the coveted newcomer of the year category in the recent Irish Book Awards since it was released in May.Critically acclaimed as a naturalist and a writer, Dara has enjoyed meteoric success this year amid also sitting his GCSEs.He said: ldquoWriting for younger children is a very special kind of conversation you have with your inner self. No word is wasted and each one carries such weight.ldquoAs a teenage author, it is such a privilege to have been afforded the opportunity to send a heartfelt message to younger children, to invite them into a world which is and always has been theirs to explore and learn from.He continued: ldquoI really hope that many children and parents will gain a dferent perspective and a new way of looking at nature on, or near, our doorsteps. Irsquom also wildly excited to connect with younger readers and families, to hear their experiences andthere are barriers to accessing nature. Irsquod really like to explore how we can narrow any gaps there might be. Together.Wild Child begins in Dararsquos back garden and takes the reader to hills, woods and ponds, with the author pointing out his favourite animals, flora and fauna.He explains all elements of the environment that fascinated him at a younger age and which continue to do so.His book also includes explanations of migration and metamorphosis, categorisation in the animal kingdom and fantastic facts on native birds, animals and plants. Each section will finish with a recommended activity for readers.Wild Child will be illustrated in colour by Barry Falls and published in hardback in July. The second book, as yet untitled, will follow in spring of ..prettyPhoto

title: Record holder Tommy voted athlete of year
story: TOMMY Hughes has won the prestigious Athletics Weekly World Masters Athlete of the Year award.The -year old former Maghera man has had a remarkable year of running achievements, despite a much reduced programme due to the Covid- pandemic.Back in October, he set a record-breaking time for athletes aged over  when he clocked .. at the Antrim Coast Half Marathon.Commenting on that performance, the judges said: ldquoTommy set a stunning world masters half-marathon record of : at Larne to even overshadow Mo Farahrsquos victory.ldquoHe also set a world indoor M m record of :. and wins the world masters male award.It is a remarkable time for someone entering his seventh decade. However, Tommy says he is nothing but thankful to running for even getting him this far.At the peak of his powers Tommy was ready to compete at the Barcelona Olympics in .He had qualied after running :: in the Marrakesh Marathon in Morocco, but a stress fracture in his foot signicantly affected him in Barcelona.The menrsquos marathon was the last event and because of the closing ceremony taking place that night, anyone with a finishing time longer than : would redirected to a finish outside the stadium. As he soldiered around the streets, he was determined to finish inside the stadium. He managed to do it, finishing nd in ...Tommy got married at , moved to Maghera, and in his own words began lsquopiling on the pounds.rsquoTo counteract that, he played Gaelic football and went for runs on his own. That provided him with something of a revelation, a passion and a huge talent, for running.At the Rotterdam Marathon in April last year, he ran ::, and in Frankfurt in October,  he teamed up with his eldest son, Eoin, to become the fastest father-son marathoners of all time. Tommy ran an over-s world record of ::, while Eoin clocked :: for a combined time of ::..prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde’s Bethany eyes gold in Japan
story: SEAFORDE swimmer Bethany Firth has been speaking about how she is drawing inspiration from her mum ahead of next yearrsquos Paralympic Games in Tokyo.Speaking in her role as an ambassador for Lidlrsquos Sport For Good initiative, the multi-gold medal winner has revealed how her mum Lindseyrsquos brave battle against cancer has given her a dferent outlook.As well as that, she has spoken of the dficulties presented to her preparations for Tokyo by coronavirus, and her desire to make an impact at the Games.ldquoMy mum was diagnosed with cancer, but she has come through that and recovered. She has been cancer free now for around a year, the -year old revealed.ldquoSeeing her, and what she has come through, has encouraged me though to keep going with things. My wonderful mum is an inspiration to me and all of our family. She has fought the disease, and had a lot of treatment and has just done so, so well.Four years ago, at the Rio Paralympics, Bethany made her mark on the world stage. A series of superb displays saw her take home three gold medals and one silver. She would become Team GBrsquos most decorated athlete of the Games.In , whilst competing for Ireland in her first Paralympics, Bethany won a gold medal at the Games in London in the S  metres backstroke final. At that stage, Bethany had been swimming for only three years. She went on to win three silver medals at the  IPC Swimming World Championships.It remains to be seen whether Bethanyrsquos family will be able to go to Tokyo next year to cheer her on, just as they did in Brazil.ldquoI would love my family to be there, Bethany admitted. ldquoI remember each time before I swam in Rio, they would tell me where they were seated and I would look across and could see them. It was like that important piece of comfort because I was so far away from home.ldquoWhen you see them, it is such a great support. My family are so good. At the moment, we donrsquot knowany spectators will be at the events. Right now, we are just hoping that the Games will go ahead.ldquoIf they take place without spectators it will be hard, but at least we will be able to compete. I was in Japan in January and got to sample what the country is like out there. That has made me even hungrier to be there next year.ldquoThe facilities werenrsquot completely built, but we saw where the athletesrsquo village would be and it looked great. Japan is an amazing country with an amazing culture and I would want to be there to represent myself and my country.Should Bethany claim more medals, it would only cement her already-assured status as one of the great Paralympians.Having to wait the extra year for the Games, due to the spread of coronavirus has, however, brought its own dficulties.ldquoWhen I heard earlier this year, that the Games had been called off, it was very hard to take because it is something that you are working towards for four years, she said.ldquoWe do other competitions of course in between though they are never as big as the Paralympics.ldquoHowever to be told they were postponed was really challenging.You have to look at the positives though.ldquoIt has given me an extra year to train and to prepare. Training was probably the hardest thing.ldquoObviously, the pools closed at the start of lockdown, so it meant Ibasically had to go out into a paddling pool in my back garden and I was on a bungee chord to get a feel for the water.ldquoSport NI and the Sports Institute Northern Ireland made up a good programme of daily things to do, so I was on the bike and running. Irsquom definitely more of a pool girl, but I canrsquot run to save my le, she joked.ldquoIt was nearly the end of the first lockdown when we were allowed to train and I had to travel to Dublin three times a week.ldquoI am now training in Ards because, thankfully, elite athletes have been allowed to train here, which is a big positive.Asthose challenges were not enough, Bethany has also been on the road to recovery from injury.ldquoI had a shoulder problem, and had to go and get that injected, so that put me out of the water for a bit a few weeks ago. But I am back in now and building the work back up.ldquoMy team and I have also looked at other areas of sport science to try and help me improve, such as tracking my sleep and making sure I am always recovered between sessions.ldquoThe British trials will be held in April and that is the main event I am focusing on at the moment. In total, I could do up to six events , but I donrsquot think I will do that many. I will definitely do four, but I am not sure about the others.ldquoI have such a love for swimming and I am really excited for the Games. Hopefully I can regain some of my titles and perform strongly again.Speaking about her link-up withthe Lidl Sport for Good programme, she said: ldquoWhat Lidl are doing is fantastic. They are giving  secondary schools pound, worth of sports equipment. It is an amazing idea to get people into sport. There are so many physical and mental benefits that come from it.ldquoIt is something that benefits the whole community, and sport can make such a positive impact on peoplersquos lives.ldquoAfter the year we have had with lockdown, and people being apart, sport can undoubtedly bring people together, and I am delighted to be able to be a part of that..prettyPhoto

quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show.
